reviews.review: another scenic location. another scenic location / route in case you are hungry for more scenic routes and like to spend time there or just walk / jog
Enjoyable run. Ran across the bridge after watching it open and close for passing water traffic. Great spectacle and good photographic opportunity.

The best walk I have ever done . The Spit to Manly walk was amazing. Beautiful views and walking through the bush. It was of medium difficulty up and down steps but it was so stimulating. I walked part of the way. 2 miles there and 2 miles back.
We had to pay $10 Aus for parking for 2.5 hours.

Coogee Lover.. The bridge is Ho Hum but the Walk from Manly to the Spit Bridge or the reverse is world class.Get a guide leaflet an do the walk early morning or late afternoon and enjoy Sydney at its best.If you get a ferry to Manly ,turn left and keep walking.,About 10 klms in all.At the Spit bridge you can get a bus or taxi back to Manly or a bus back to the city.

Vital Transport Link. The Spit Bridge, connecting the Sydney North Shore suburbs of Mosman and Seaforth, has played a vital part in the development of Sydney from Seaforth right up to Palm Beach, 40 km to the north. Without the Spit Bridge, access to these northern beach side suburbs would have been via other harbour crossings, involving much longer and more complicated routes.At the beginning of the 20th Century, the only crossing was by punt, a slow and frustrating procedure for those in a hurry.In 1924 the first Spit Bridge was built, a low-level timber bridge.This was replaced in 1958 with the current bridge, a steel and concrete girder bridge, with a bascule lift span to allow yachts and other boats passage across Middle Harbour, which is part of Sydney Harbour.The Spit Bridge is also either the start of finish, depending which way you walk, of the famous Manly to Spit Harbour-side walk.

Must do - Spit Bridge to Manly walk. Highly recommended. Offers beautiful views of the the city and Sydney Harbour. Hard to believe that one is still in the city while walking through the bushland. And of course a ferry ride back to finish it off makes for a great and affordable day out in Sydney
Views, Views and more views.. Not easy going after rain. Plenty of spots to stop and sit and take in the views or take a dip in the harbour. Well signposted. Good exercise!

One of the most beautiful walks I've ever done. A relatively easy-going, refreshing yet stunning costal walk (3 hours start to finish...) which takes you through some amazing secluded beaches, pristine sands, small coastal towns and finishes off up high up on the cliffs with a breath-taking view of the North and South Heads before heading into Manly.

A very special walk. Having done the walk in September you not only have superb views of Sydney Harbour and great weather (not too hot) but have the joy of seeing the many wildflowers that are out.This to me is one of the great walks around this magnificent harbour.Well worth the effort.

Brilliant Day Out. we bussed to the Spit Bridge and walked the longer of the two options (12 - 14kms) following beautiful paths that traced the coastline affording tantalising glimpses up towards some grand 'harbourside mansions' and down towards the occasional moored yacht bobbing away happily in little coves, and enjoyed a variety of stunning vistas and varieties of wildflowers as well as a little swim break at Clontarf Beach which is on the route, then the final section wends down through residential streets to the harbour ferry terminal, where we caught the ferry to Circular Quay... a stunning walk, not difficult, but take a bottle of water... happily there are no shops along the way!
Beautiful nature walk in the city!. A wonderful path along the sea and in the residential neighborhoods, ending up in Manly where you can join a meal and relax on the beach with a swim in the sea!

This is a very good walk with lovely views.. One sets out from the Spit Bridge which is in a beautiful setting - then it takes you through some of the most lovely parts of Sydney with stunning views across the harbour and the Pacific Ocean when you get to Manly.

Great views, great exercise. This was a great experience for us. The views were spectacular but we weren't expecting such a great variety. From sandy beaches, rugged cliffs, thick forest that could have been a million miles from anywhere to beautiful suburban homes this walk had everything. It was also a fantastic workout with the hills and steps making us really earn the nice lunch we had at the end in downtown Manly. This walk is a must do for everyone

Beautiful views!. Basically a 6 mile hike with many, many stairs, both up and down. Lots of uneven surfaces. Not for the faint of heart. But the views were fantastic! Take your time and enjoy. Bring water!
Great walk. This is one of the great walks on Sydney's North Shore, great views along the way, and reasonably easy stroll.

Good walk. I did this walk and it was fantastic. Only issue was there were a few detours and one of them pointed you in the wrong direction which added about half an hour onto the walk.Would recommend doing as it is lovely and scenic just watch for the detours.
boring and waste of time. Boring , can't even find the path, poorly maintained facilities, and poor signs, can't even find my way, waste of time, takes a long time to go there too, dont bother

Stunning views superb walk. Treat yourself to stunning coastal cliff face views, indigenous bush, beaches, and sea stretching way into the distance. A wonderful treat on a sunny day; complement the beautiful walk with a good meal in Manly or Spit Bridge... (or both!)

Amazing way to appreciate this wonderful city . Really easy walk with the most spectacular views of Sydney harbour.Hint: start at Clontarf Reserve with free street parking, walk to Manly for lunch than a cheap Uber back to your car.

Much more relaxed than Bondi - Coogee walk. It was an awesome walk from Manly beach to Spit Bridge. The 10 km we made in 3 hours. Actually we were wondering the difficulty of this walk. It was mentioned with gentle - medium but we think it it rather medium. If you want to do the whole turn you need to be quiet fit as there are a lot of stairs/steps. It was a very nice walk with almost no people which was surprising. We fully recommend this walk. It was beautiful and a highlight so far. The Bondi to Coogee instead was also nice as well but very crowded.

A beautiful walk with great views. This is an excellent alternative to Bondi to Coogee Coastal Walk. Perhaps a little longer but more varied as it passes through green vegetation as well as beaches with many great picnic spots along the way. The view of the harbour and over to Manly are breathtaking. Highly recommended even in not so good weather. Take a bus from Wynyard that goes via the Spit Bridge; ask the driver where to get off. The beginning of the track is reasonably easy to find, just under the bridge on the north-east side. Once on the walking path it is pretty straightforward although you have options to take side paths to mini beaches or view points. Along the way you will see lizards that might come quite close if you happen to sit down and eat an apple! In spring time you can see many wild flowers. There is one beach that you will have to cross continuing in the normal direction. If there is high tide you might need to take off your shoes as the strip of sand between houses and the bay is narrow. Once you are near Manly you again have to watch a little where you are going but the signposting has improved over the years and there are usually others you can ask for direction. Once in Manly, you may wish to visit the famous ocean beach before taking a ferry back to downtown and the Opera House. A great day / half day program!

Great two hour walk. It's a good 10k, 2 hour walk with some of the best views of the beautiful Sydney harbour. Take plenty of water and have a well earned bite to eat in Manley at the end. Would recommend catching the bus or taxi back to your staring point as I wouldn't like to turn round and do the all again!

A great walk. We took the Manly Ferry from Circular Quay to Manly where we started our walk. We are both in our seventies, the walk took us about three hours. Amazing views along the way. I don't think it is a walk that I would do in the heat of summer, as the last part is quite open. There are frequent bus services from the Spit to take you back to Manly where you can enjoy a delicious meal.

Amazing walk, proposed to my wife on it. A really good long walk, breath taking views, a good work out and a fun day out. It takes around 2 hours start to finish but plenty of amazing places to stop and enjoy the view. Gets a bit snakey/lizardy in summer but worth it to end up in beautiful Manly
Lovely walk with breathtaking views. Easy walk from Spit bridge will take you through National Park. Follow the coast. Plenty of benches to sit, relax and enjoy the view.

Breathtaking Views. We did this walk a few weeks ago on a beautiful sunny day. The views were magic & the walk was a little challenging if you have bad knees or feet. We were blown away by the views and upon arrival at Manly Beach had the most beautiful fish & chips, followed by an indulgent ice cream. We then walked it all off on the way back as we felt guilt, however, it is easy to catch public transport back if you prefer.

Another great walk can be done in half a day. Great walk with super nice views. In summer plenty options for a swim. It is an easy half day walk if done from Spit Bridge. But if you do it from Taronga Zoo it can be extended to a nice full day walk. Plenty of after walk options in Manly :-)

Stunning Views. Take a bus (recommended) to the Fisher Bay Reserve near the Spit Bridge and stroll along the cliffs overlooking Middle Harbour. Takes about 3 hours. Recommend lunch (and a few drinks) at the Manly Skiff Club and then take the ferry back to Circular Key for a full day's enjoyment.
A must do!. Beautiful way too see Sydney! Start off early and take it slowly to enjoy the beaches along the way. Stop off a Clonny's cafe for some walking snacks

Free! No need to pay for tours. The walk is really nice to do and in one side and the other many public transportations! No need to pay for tours.For toddlers may be a little too much the entire walk.Loved doing it and will do it again for sure!!

Beautiful walk!. This is an amazing walk...one of a kind views. The trail was relatively mild...although there were a lot of ups and downs with steps built into the trail. So if you had bad knees or have trouble with stairs this may be tough. Otherwise a great trail and would be suitable for most fitness level. A must due on a nice weather say.
Stunning walk. Absolutely stunning place to walk about .. incredibly clear views of the bay /harbours .. the air is so fresh and even tastes clean

Beautiful Views. It might take you 2 - 3 hours and you probably need to have some fitness, but it is so worthwhile. The scenery is stunning. Pack some nibbles and stop along the way to enjoy the great outdoors. We took our time, stopping for photos and coffee along the way and had a picnic ... we found the walk easy and great fun. Once at Manly, we enjoyed a refreshing ale before taking the ferry back to Sydney. Yes, you can do the return walk, but we ran out of daylight !!! A must do when in Sydney.

Beautiful walk. We did the walk with our 2 kids ages 10 and 11. The walk is absolutely beautiful. We took the ferry from Circular Quay to the Manly ferry stop and walked back toward Spit. *There is an amazing candy stand when you get off the ferry! We made it halfway back before it started raining and the kids began to complain so we called an Uber and ditched the walk. If we have time I would love to complete the walk. It was gorgeous scenery! Don't forget to bring some water with you. There are also a few toilets along the way (but not many).

Want a Workout with Stunning Views?. Much longer and more intense than the Coogee to Bondi walk, this walk offers a myriad of experiences....uphill climbs and downhill walks through bush, beach, parks and local streets.Make sure you plan your trip well as it will take you 3 hours one way and you need to factor in travel times depending on where you are coming from. We caught a train to the city, a bus to The Spit, did the walk to Manly and then caught the ferry back to Circular Quay and train home.We went in the cooler months which was very pleasant but I believe those that do it in the warmer months, take extra time to jump in for a swim at different beaches along the way, to cool off.Whichever time of the year you do this walk, you won't be disappointed.

perfect views around the harbour and a great morning walk.. Great mix of bush, beach and views. Take plenty of water and get ready for some stairs and a decent climb. I took the 9 year old and he coped well with plenty to look at and do. Allow 2 - 3 hours and then enjoy Manly at the end. If you eat too much there....walk back

LOOKING FOR A HALF DAY WALK IN SYDNEY?. Nice fine day in Sydney and not certain what to do ? Then try the Spit Bridge to Manly walk .I once dropped off a Scottish friend of mine at the Spit Bridge and said he could walk to Manly where he was staying . I did however forget to tell him its a 3 hr to 4 hour walk depending your pace and how long you linger . It is though one of the best walks in Sydney and not difficult really. Try it and you won't be disappointed . Easy access out of Sydney via a bus service or walk it the opposite way from Manly and catch the bus back to the city . Food is available at the Spit and at Manly

Decent hike, spectacular views! . Myself and 2 friends did this walk a couple weeks back, it was amazing!You'll need to be reasonably fit as its a 10km walk and some parts are quite steep. We started at manly, walked to the spit and bused it back to manly after. Id recommend good walking shoes, plenty of water and a camera. We saw a lot of birds along the way including yellowtail black cockatoos and various other smaller species. The highlight is always reef beach! Take swimmers if you go during the warmer months, reef beach is a perfect spot to stop for a dip.
We did this with family. If you are keen for a great walk with fantastic views of Sydney Harbour, this is a good activity with anyone. Maybe not for small children.

Fantastic day out. You need to be reasonably fit to do this walk. There are parts where it is somewhat difficult.. The views are spectacular, and a great way to exercise in the fresh air.. In spring the wild flowers bloom. There are a couple of places to stop and swim, have a picnic or just relax and enjoy the views. Sunscreen, hat and water bottle are recommended.
Beautiful sites. A very good place to see the Harbours beauty , lovely walks and scenery , suitable for all ages, check out all these places for the disabled before you go.

Amazing trekking on Sunday morning. I did this walk twice already and would do it again! The scenic is amazing and it's not too hard, so a beginner can also do it. But it will take you 2-4 hours to finish it from Spit Bridge to Manly wharf, but it's worthy! There's cafes on the way and you will stop for photos a few times too. At the end you can reward yourself having some food in one of the countless good restaurants in Manly.

Spectacular views, beautiful walk, must do!!. If you take the bus, please let the driver know you are getting off at the Spit Bridge; otherwise you have to walk back and find the sign of 'Scenic Manly Walk' and it isn't that easy. However once you get it, just keep following the well-marked route.Cross The Spit Bridge on the Middle Harbour side and walk into the car park and find the steps leading down under the Bridge to the start of the Track. You will see the stunning views from the waterfront before disappearing into the bushes. There are toilets clearly marked at strategic points. You can choose to have a picnic along the way it just stop and enjoy the quietness.When you arrive at Manly you can spend time at the gallery or have lunch at the restaurant nearby (very new it seemed) or just take the ferry that takes you to Circular Quay (duration is 30 mins)and you get a wonderful view of the Sydney Opera House and the Harbour.

Must do activity when in Sydney!. This was a great activity to do and affords one the opportunity to get out of the busy sydney for a while. The walk is splendid, mostly with views of the water but still well covered by trees. The route is also well marked and approximately 9 kilometers. A fantastic way to burn off some of the extra holiday calories. I walked on a very hot day, and enjoyed every moment! Remember to take water and sunblock!Once you arrive at Manly spend some time at the wonderful beach the way the Ausies do it , and grab something to eat. We ended of a great day by taking the ferry back to Circular Quay...
Varied scenery. This walk traverses forested National park & coastal walking. Long, but varied with shade a welcome relief in the heat.
Unforgettable Coastal Walk. Its a beautiful scenic walk with a view of the city and the pacific ocean. Its a must going attraction in NSW.

Brilliant Winters Day Walk. Heard a lot about this walk but had been put off by the logistics of it not being a round trip for walk. However we parked at the Spit Bridge end on the Manly side and Uber back to the car for $15 between 4 of us so better than a bus! Scenery to die for with new views around every corner and a good work out for an afternoon. Track was narrow in places so needed to be aware of other walkers and we missed the turn off to the lighthouse ( next time) . Plenty of up and down so those who are after the exercise this is great. Personally I think this suits the cooler months and finish with a meal in Manly. I must do with active over seas visitors.

Nice but wouldn't do it more than once. Getting here by public transport is a bit of a nightmare, our bus dropped us off by a main highway and we had to bolt across the road to get to the starting point of the walk, it was quite confusing. The walk itself is nice, lovely scenery and you can even reach some Aboriginal carvings in the cliff. You eventually reach a few beaches which is nice but they're quite dirty and I wouldn't advise to swim in them. It was nice to see that part of Sydney but I'm not rushing to do the walk again any time soon.

City hike with a bush feel. A bit busy and congested in parts but overall a wonderful walk. Watch for the big muddy puddles if it has been wet. The signage was a bit hit and miss resulting in us taking a strange suburban detour. All part of the adventure though.

Great day out. Walk one way and bus baack. Beautiful beaches. Great for summer or spring and Autumn. Average fitness required. Lookouts over the harbour. Finish your day with a glass of wine at Manly wharf

❤️My favorite trail in Sydney. Highly recommend❣️I went to with my co-woker after long flight from Vancouver Canada. It took 3 and half hours. Even though we were jet lag tried but we really enjoyed so much❣️
Surrounding beautiful nature and awesome cost line❣️Enjoy❣️Cheers❣️

Skip the Spit Bridge and start in the Clontarf gardens.. Personally, I dont like the spit Bridge so when doing the walk I start in the Clontarf reserve. Parking is better and getting back there is easier too. It's an easy walk, for keen walkers of all ages. The views are just amazing. My favourite bit is around the Grotto Point Make sure you don't miss the aboriginal engravings when there. There are no toilets and no food to buy on the walk. So , either stock up in the Clontarf cafes or in Manly. ALso, I don't think there are any water fountains, so make sure you have sufficient amount of water with you. The walk is partly shaded but still make sure you have a hat, camera and some snacks.Let the views, the ocean and the bay do the rest. It's so rewarding and recharging you will feel miles away.

Beautiful Bush walk with all the Comforts. A great scenic way to see Sydney's Middle Harbour as you stroll along the coastline up and down. But you are never very far from a kiosk or Cafe. Highly recommend. It do during the week if possible as it can get busy on the weekend!
in top three walks in sydney. This is definitely one of the nest walks in Sydney. Beautiful Manly, around the foreshores with great views out to the heads.

Some of the best harbour views in the world. This walk (on which I proposed to my wife, so it has special significance!) is about six different walks in one - there's forest, scrub, clifftops, beaches and views, all wrapped up in a couple of hours of beautiful walking. The path is carefully maintained, and if you walk Spit to Manly, there's ice cream at the Manly end too!

Worthwhile challenge. This is a demanding walk that will take 2-3 hours each way. The views are amazing so it is well worth it. The track is mostly unsealed, though at the Manley end you walk on road and concrete paths. The grade is mostly easy, but there are some steps and a few short steep pitches. Great to leave the car at the Spit (plenty of parking) walk to Manley for lunch, and enjoy the stroll back to your car in the mid afternoon.
Sydney Walks not to be missed. This walk is not only spectacular it provides an amazing opportunity to see parts of Sydney that can appear to be hidden and yet are available to all and sundry.
Spit to Manly Walk. Excellent walk along the coast line with great views.Takes around 2 hours and 1.5 hours if just walking and not stopping often.

Just beautiful ..... This is a beautiful walk. Not strenuous but long if you are unfit. Bring a small picnic to have along the way as there is nothing along the way where you could buy a drink or food. We did it from Spit Bridge and it is well sign-posted. The vegetation and views change along the way but we loved the whole walk.

Great hike with spectacular views. The trail is about 10km long and quite hilly, but still it only took us 2 hours to finish instead of the 3-4 hours they said. this is one of the better walks to do in the Sydney area.

Sydney bridge walk. Well I am not one for the heights but once you get over that fear and it is perfectly safe you are tethered to the bridge at all times and the staff is truly experienced and well trained. Take this tour and walk the bridge the sights are unbelievable and the views are unsurpassed. It is fun and all ages and physical types can do it.

Gorgeous views. I finally did this walk last year after hearing about it from others. It didn't disappoint - the views were spectacular and the hike was long enough without being too physically strenuous. The trail is very well maintained, and meanders through vegetation, alongside rock ledges, past hidden beaches etc. Will definitely do again.
Best views in Sydney. Highly recommended for some fresh air, great coastal views and a good workout. The track is about 9kms long and quite hilly so be prepared.

Great walk and spectacular views. This is a moderate 9.5km. walk which you can take in either direction. It follows the harbour around to the Sydney Heads where ships enter and leave Sydney's beautiful harbour. While there are some steps and hill climbs, it is suitable for all ages if you take your time, anywhere from 2-4 hours, depending on your level of fitness.

Great walk. Spit Bridge to Manly as opposed to the other way is the best way to do this walk. You finish on the flatter part of the walk and ending in Manly gives you café/lunch options that don't exist at the Spit Bridge end and better transport options to go home. The walk is a good 2.5 hours and well worth it. You don't need to be an experienced walker but it is very up and down so you need to be good on your feet ie not for wobbly grannies. Great opportunities to also have a dip in Middle Harbour on the way if you wanted to.

One of Sydney's great walks. This walk will take you from The Spit through the Fisher Bay Walk, Sandy Bay and Clontarf, before getting through the Sydney harbour National park and jilling Cove into Manly Cove. A minimum level off fitness is required to negotiate some hilly terrain in the Sydney Harbour National Park, rewarded with great harbour views. The perfect plan for a sunny day, preferably out of summer.

10 km walk The Spit Bridge to Manly Walk. I did the Spit Bridge to Manly walk with my 11 year old son last year. The 10 km walk is a great experience for my son who basically loves the amazing sights , beaches & coastal walk. Passing along the beautiful ,idyllic places, sacred to the Aboriginals before the development took place. Seeing the water dragon lizard up close & personal, wildlife plants and the serenity and stillness of the place once you reached the top of the hill is unimaginable. Walking along the coastline is a magical experience especially for a 11 year young boy. Although , there are some spot that you lose signal from your mobile but not for long. I'll strongly recommend to pack some food & snacks, bring a lot water. Autumn is a good season to do the walk. The highlights of the walk is you get to jump in any local beaches after the walk before you head home. Buses are frequent that travel to the city after the walk of you can head back to Manly beach and take ferry going back to the Circular Quay.

The Best (FREE) Sydney Attraction. This is one of the best things you can do when you’re in Sydney!Beaches (tick). Famous Sydney coastline (tick). Free (tick).Pack your day bag with a small picnic lunch, catch a bus to the Spit Bridge and begin your adventure! We took just under four hours to complete the trek – that’s including spotting umpteen times to snap stunning landscapes, a 45-minute break at Reef Beach and a slow ‘n’ steady pace. Take plenty of water, sunscreen and your swimmers – there are no shops or cafes on route until the very end in Manly.

My favorite coastal /bushland walk in Sydney!. This is Sydney's best walk! It takes you through some secluded beaches, bays and inlets and amazing parts of the bushland.The walk include a combination of sand, flat, steep, stairs and rocky walks- but it is well sign-posted and there are plenty of water taps and toilets on the way.We mostly start with a take away coffee at the Clontarf beach and then start our walk from there. But if you are up for the challenge then it will be worth starting from Balmoral Beach.It takes about 3hrs 30min, so make sure you have a snack handy, as there are no cafes or shops until you reach Manly.Keep an eye on the water as you might be treated to the whales or the penguins.

One of the best walks in Sydney. Do yourself a favour when you have a day to spare and do this walk. You can drive to the Spit Bridge and find a car park the catch a bus back up from Manly when you finish the walk. OR Catch a bus to the Spit from the City and go back on the Manly Ferry- more fun.You probably wont have the walk to yourself as its popular with the locals as well, so look out for mad runners belting through the scrub.Plenty of variety in the walk from walking through scrub to walking along beside white beaches and sparkling water or looking out over the magnificent Sydney Harbour with all its activity as you descend towards your destination. I suggest you take a picnic lunch with you and sit on one of the lovely little beaches for your lunch.A gem.

Fantastic and challenging trail run!. Of course you can enjoy this walk just as much by walking the 10km, yet today I felt like a little more exercise, and ran most of it - choosing to walk all the steep stair sections. This walk requires good shoes, drinking water, and being prepared for 2 hours or more of challenging ups and downs. There are toilets close to the Manly portion of the walk, yet you are very isolated for much of it, especially from Clontarf reserve to forty baskets beach. Take sunscreen, sunglasses and a hat on sunny days, and maybe even a snack to enjoy the lookouts!

Long beautiful walk. Started this walk at spit bridge at Mosman and took me all way to manly . its 10 km walk with some most beautiful views of the places . You can take the bus to spit bridge or you can park somewhere and then enjoy your walk . Make sure you take heaps of photos as views are breathtaking

Perfect scenic walk. This walk was in my list for so long and I am so glad that it didn't disappoint me. in fact it was amazing walk. Though I read somewhere that between May-November is a season when you can spot whales on this walk but I didn't have that luck. Having said so, I enjoyed this walk fully. I stared from Spit Bridge and walked till manly. If you are going from City, you can take bus # 178 which takes approx 25 mints to reach The spit. I travelled on Sunday, so frequency of the bus was once in an hour.The walk is somewhere between Easy to medium (there are few steps) at some places. I could spot some elderly people as well as people with toddlers on the way. But you cannot take strollers on this walk.It takes approximately 3 hours if you halt occasionally for couple of minutes as it's 10 kms long stretch- perfect for a day outing. There are some small beaches on the way where you can take dip if you like.

Well maintained track with great views.. I did this walk with a friend on a beautifully clear autumn day. We started by crossing Spit Bridge (there are many buses which stop just before the bridge) and picking up the clearly marked coastal path. The 10km walk winds around picturesque headlands and through harbour side bush and past plenty of secluded beaches (perfect for a swim on a hot day!). There are also marked places of Aboriginal importance, so make sure you check out some amazing rock carvings, and take a look at the view out to sea while you are there. Some of the lookouts face back towards the city and others provide a beautifully clear view out to North and South Head and the sea. There are a few places scattered along the walk that would make good lunch stops, or it is possible to do the walk and make it to Manly in time for lunch (as we did). Some of the track is quite exposed and there is not always a lot of shade so definitely take a hat, sunscreen and plenty of water, as well as sturdy shoes as there are some steep inclines and steps. This is a great way to spend half a day (or stretch it out for a full day). There is plenty to do at Manly and the ferry is the easiest (and most enjoyable) way to get back to Circular Quay. This is a great way to see some iconic places in Sydney and to get outside for the day.

Great walk with beautiful seanery . It is a lovely walk, about 10 km since one of the last part was close and you need to take the detour. The scenery is lovely and you can stop along the way and rest at the different beaches. Very important to carry enough water and food, especially if you have young kids with you.

Your vitality will be restored whilst watching Sydney Harbour sparkle.. Sydney Harbour is beautiful. During the summer months we enjoy the best of the both the Harbour and Surfing Beaches. During the cooler months we love the walks between Mosman and Manly. My children love this walk and the adventure of discovering new parts of nature. The Spit Bridge to Manly Walk is an easy walk. You will experience the beautiful beaches, walk through the National Park, listen to the birds sing and reward yourself in Manly with a coffee, gelato or mineral water. Become revitalised as you immerse yourself in one of Sydney’s most beautiful walks.

,lovely walk. The walk took about three hours but we did stop and pic nic on the way. You pass some lovely beaches and we wished we could have stopped for a swim. It was rather hot the day we walked so maybe late morning early afternoon was not a good time! We came back on the ferry. A lovely walk so close to a busy city. Loved Manly so different from Sydney, very laid back.

An easy enough walk aroubd a superb area of the inner harbour. This is a wonderful walk. Do not be put off by the distance - take your togs, stop off along the way - refresh, eat a picnic, it is a wonderful way to experience a lsow take on a great part of Sydney. Bus from the CND, get off at the Spit Bridge, end at Manly and take the freey back to the Quay. Wonderful. Don't forget the official nude bach on the way for a swimmers free dip!

Amazing harbour views. There are some incredible views along this walk- it's hard to believe that you are in the middle of the city! On a clear day the harbour sparkles & the gentle hum of the native bush is very calming. Ok, it's not a walk for your Granny on her frame- but most people could manage it, if you take your time.

Long, But Beautiful!. I use to walk along this walk for school sport and it would feel like it took hours on end (views of a 15 year old school girl years ago) but in all honesty, if you enjoy the outdoors, love the water and long walks you can not go wrong with he Spit Bridge to Manly Walk! its beautiful and very peaceful! i would strongly suggest be aware in later hours of the evening as I once ran along this walk a few years ago and caught a man in the bushes doing things he shouldn't have been doing. We reported it, but they never found the man. just be careful as it is along bush, water, and paths that can be hidden from everyday people.

Amazing views, pretty easy walk. If you are visiting Sydney, or if you are a local and haven't done this walk yet, it's a must do. Take a sandwich and stop at any of the hidden beaches or look outs on the way, and finish up your afternoon having a drink and Manly before catching a ferry back across the harbor. I literally could not imagine a better walk to take visitors on to show off Sydney's beauty.

Gorgeous walk on a fine day. This is one of Sydney's great walks; in fact possibly one of the best walks in the world. You'll need decent shoes and a smidgen of energy to make it up the steep spots but the walk rewards with plenty of places to stop for a swim along the way and sensational coastal views. Drive or bus to Spit Bridge and take the bus back from Manly or ferry into the city. Make sure you reward yourself when you get to Manly - plenty of places for a cold beer, delicious ice cream or snack.

Wish we had more time. We visited Australia in April and a few people from Oz recommended doing this walk as it was beautiful. Unfortuantely we ran out of time and never got to do it but will be doing this when we return. If the locals recommend it, it must be something worth doing.

Fantastic coastal Walk. Walking through a mix of bushland and scenic harbourside trails, the 10 km Manly to Spit Bridge coastal walk is made of short tracks. You will be passing some of stunning beaches. The walk took us around 3 hours to finish it. Highly recommended if you are in Sydney for few days.

Fabulous walk along Sydney foreshore. Lovely walk along the most beautiful shore in the world.The walk takes about 3 hours long in a leisurely pace (and kids in tow). Make sure you have good walking shoes specially if it has been raining a day or two before you go. On a hot day, bring your swimmers and take a dip in the few beaches that you will find along the way. Bring water and sunscreen with you.Do the walk as early as you can. The walkway gets very busy from both direction.
Magnificent. The walk was worth every moment. Very picturesque. Planning is required to get back to the start, but nothing remarkable comes without a little effort.

Sydney's No. 1 attraction. It doesn't get better than this. It's quite a distance and will take half a day, but it's worth it. Lovely beaches, stunning harbour views, fabulous houses and an easy to follow path. I'm a Sydneysider but I've done a lot of travelling and I'd put this up against pretty much anything the world has to offer. If I had to recommend one thing to do in Sydney, this would be it.

Bushwalking from Manly.. If you've done the Bonid to Coogee, Shelley Beach and North Head. Been across the Harbour near Tarronga zoo. The next inner city nature experience is the Manly to Spit Bridge walk. It's about 10 km and well worth it. Once you've done this one, your ready for Kurringai National Park and the amazing southern Royal National Park.

Worth the effort. Go on-line and work out which bus to catch to get to Spit Bridge. It's a 20 - 30 minute trip depending on the traffic. The walk winds around the bays before climbing up through the bush to above the tree line. Magnificent views. Then a descent back to the sea where Manly is visible "just over" the other side of the water. But don't be fooled, there is still a fair way to go. It's well signed. A moderate level of fitness is needed since the track undulates most of the way, and some bits are reasonably steep. Relax on the ferry back to Sydney

Beautiful walk from Manly to SpitBridge. We took a ferry from Circular Quay to Manly. As soon as we came out of Ferry, we saw the board pointing the way to spit bridge walk. There are many pointers on the way except at a point where there were flight of stairs going up and down the hill. Here there is no clear indication which way to the spit bridge. So we took the steps going down towards the beach and started proceeding climbing boulders until such time that it became difficult making us to retreat and take the steps going uphill. We lost about 20 minutes in this little confusion. Towards the end when we reached the sandy beach again we didn't see any pointers to spit bridge. Other than these two drawbacks it was a lovely walk which we took about 4 hours to complete. My 6 yr old son and 60 yr old father could complete this walk with little difficulty. It involves some climbing on the hills and a little bit on the sandy beach but mostly we were walking on paved pathways.

Fantastic Hike - in the city but in the bush!. Great hike. Did it in 2007 and last month in 2016. Well maintained trail (they were overhauliung parts of it in March 2016). On a hot day it is a bit of a slog, but again well maintained and great footings. You move in and out of views of the city and of Manly, interspersed with just bush walking. Nice elevated views of the water and coastlines, then down to sea level. Highly recommended. Take a bus, uber or taxi (come on, get a Opal car, easy bus ride) to the Spit. Trail is marked. At Manly, grab lunch at the pier on the ferry side- Hugos has GREAT pizza. Then ferry back to the city. A wonderful morning.

A great coastal walk. We did this walk on 9 April and the weather was perfect. The route is well shaded so you aren't in constant sunshine but it is hot so make sure you take some water with you. There is one point along the way where you can fill up your water bottle if needed.We took the bus from Sydney which is really convenient and then returned on the Manly ferry. Fantastic views and plenty to see. Wear shoes or trainers appropriate for walking because even on a dry days there are wet patches. The ferry back is the perfect way to round off the walk, which takes approx 3 hours at a leisurely pace.

An amazing nature walk in along the harbour. One of the best city walks. Up there with Bondi to Bronte, but much more secluded. This is a bit of a longer walk, but certainly one you cannot miss if you love walks. Start at Middle Harbour and make your way all the way around to the Manlay harbour...

Excellent walk for locals and tourists alike. Outstanding views. Take a picnic and swimmers and make a day of it. Good transport back from the Spit to Manly for visitors - just check bus timetables before you go.

unmissable if you want to experience sydney harbour coastal walk. fantastic walk can really just take your time ..we took 4 hours and ended up at manly wharf for late lunch and drinks before taking the ferry back to the city

Good view with broken part. The view along the coast was great, but there are a lot of broken path through some park and road, as well the view have some building (manly side). Personally i will recommend coogee to bondi beach, the sea view are breath taking. How to get here: take bus from wynyard train station, stand C at Carrington street, a lot of bus from there, 178, 179 and 180 (more bus i supposed ). Stop before the bridge, and walk under it to the other side of the bridge and walk across the bridge. The walk start here.The route can be pretty heavy at certain point, but mostly are fine, look for the sign MSW (manly scenic walk) for the direction. When you arrived at manly, do not forget to go to 4 pines micro brewery, it's great bar (separate review ).

Don't miss this hidden gem of Sydney!. If beautiful, stunning, hidden paths, beaches, coves and view points are what you after this walk will not fail to disappoint. But on your walking shoes, this one is for the able bodied, I'd leave the little ones at home. Bring sunscreen and water. I would recommend a snack and swimmers to stop off at one of the beaches on the way. Enjoy!

Probably the most beautiful harbour walk in Sydney. We usually walk from Manly to the Spit and then get the bus back but it is equally beautiful in either direction. We just like having Brekky and coffee at Plonk (beautiful cafe at Spit Bridge overlooking the wharf). There are so many amazing spots to stop and picnic or swim on the way. You could probably do it in a couple of hours if your really got a march on but don't, take your time and soak it in. Allow 3-4 hours or more if you want to make a day of it. This is a "must do"...put it on your Sydney bucket list!!!

A stunning day out!!. If you have a day off to enjoy the natural beauty of the northern coast line in Sydney, don't miss out on this beautiful walk!! This 10km walk takes you thru private beaches and coves and stunning harbour views. It's very accessible with public transport on both sides of the walk. Pack a picnic lunch and water as there are many spots to sit and enjoy yourself. :D

Great walk!. We did this walk on February 28th. We took bus to the Spit Bridge and after the walk - ferry from Manly to Sydney Harbor.It is a 10km walk that took us approximately 3.5 hours to complete with many stops for picture taking and stop for a swim on one of the smaller rocky beaches along the way. It was very hot. There are some places that are completely open with no shade; we burnt badly (especially ears and necks) even with sunscreen, because it was hot and sweaty. The worst combinations for me were steps up in completely open spaces on hot sun. There is also detour in the end of the walk.The walk offers spectacular views of the entrance to the harbor and over to the city, Downtown. Loved the Doggie Beach, our dogs would love it. I would do this walk again in some other season, not summer. The walk is beautiful, definitely would recommend it.The views from Manly Ferry were beautiful as well.

Fantastic walk - but give yourself enough time. This is a great walk if you are into such things but do give yourself enough time so you can linger, stop for a swim (or two) and get lost if you want to (or if it happens accidentally)and don't rush. And don't leave in the heat of the day. Part way through you will be in blazing sun (assuming it is summer) and this is the part where it is easier to take a wrong turn. Take plenty of water. Give yourself 4-5 hours to take your time and enjoy the views.
Scenic walking. A well worn and signposted walk offering great views of the magnificent harbour and its environs several hour walk but plenty of transport options available at either end

Tiring. Did this walk on Saturday I think the weather was perfect for it. About 28 so not to hot but still warm enough to go for a swim. The views are amazing and some of the rock beaches near the spit reminded me of Thailand.

Discover a whole new side to Sydney Harbour. A three hour walk that takes you past private beaches, bush-clad inlets and breath-taking views of Sydney Harbour. Even if you are a local, this walk is a 'must' in order to see the Harbour like never before. The track is manageable and the bus trip back to Spit Bridge car park is regular and relatively direct. TIP - Make sure you pack your swimmers for a dip in Manly Beach when you reach your destination. A brilliant way to relax if the sun is out!!

Wonderful way to see the northern shore of the harbour. One of the many great walks along the harbour. Leave your car near the bus stop on the north side of the spit and walk all the way along the coast (including a couple of suburban streets) until you get to Manly Wharf, where you can get a bus back to your car, or you can get the bus all the way to the city. Take your swimmers and have a dip on the way.

Great views of the Harbour. Easter Friday 2016 - Manley Wharf to Spit Bridge. Well marked walk through National Parkland. Stop along the way to take in the views across the harbour & watch the Manly ferry cut its way to Circular Quay. Take drinks and a snack - there are no shops along the way. Take a moment to see the engravings along the track near the Grotto.There were heaps of family with kids. You can access little beaches along the way too. Took about 3 hours at a leisurly pace.I took the ferry to Manly to start, and a bus from the Spit Bridge at the end into the CBD.

A demanding but worthwhile walk. The walking tour from Spit to Manly is a demanding walk that takes you through wilderness, forest, Aboriginal history, famtastic views and finishes in Manly, where you can purchase a much needed meal. The tour takes a 3 hours (we did it in 2 1/2, but we're young and took no breaks).

Beautiful way to grasp Sydney Harbour any time during the year.. Make this a round trip. You'll need a day .Take a bus to the spit. You 'll find the walk on the north side of the bridge.The walk is full of surprises with great snap shots of the Harbour.It can be busy but still very pleasant.Take some food and water as there is not too many place to eat on the way. But on your arrival in Manly, you'll find many beautiful food places. Take the ferry back to Circular Quay and that will complete a Fantastic day !

Moderate level of fitness level.. Great walk. I live in Sydney and have done this walk many times. Secluded beaches and views across the harbour. Mainly flat walk shaded by vibrant angaphoras (beautiful gum trees with rust coloured bark). The walk is around 12kms but is steady and not too taxing. Take a bottle of water, wear your swimming costume and take a dip in the pool at Fairlight then continue around to manly for lunch.
One of many stunning walks!. You just can not fault this entire area. Each walk is breathtaking and picture perfect. Great picnic locations and fresh salty air everywhere you go!
what a walk!!. Quite difficult in parts - lots of climbing steps and or rocks - but very clearly marked. take your own water.

Something you must do when visiting Sydney. The walk will take you to an amazing journey, look around you as you will find some wild life animals and enjoy some beautiful landscapes. Be sure to bring your swimsuit as you will encounter some nice beaches along the path.The path will take 2 hours more or less (according to your speed and if you often stop to take picture), take some water with you as there won't be anything to buy any along the track. Also, there are a lot of steps so I wouldn't recommend it for a pregnant woman or an elder person.

Great for Pics. This iconic walk, whilst exhausting, provides beautiful lookouts allowing a glimpse of the gorgeous coast. This walk is perfect for tourists, wanting some great memories and also locals alike. Just don't go in the heat of a day without a water bottle.

A must do!. We took the bus from Carrington Street (behind Wynyard Station) and got off at Spit Bridge. Decided to do it in reverse to take advantage of the facilities at Manly at the end. There appeared to be a couple of restaurants at the Spit Bridge and also toilets in the park. It had rained heavily the night before so the path was very wet and muddy in places, definitely wear very good walking shoes. We stopped in the park at Clontarf to eat lunch (there is a kiosk there as well as toilets and a place to fill a water bottle) Not sure how this took some previous reviewers less than 2 hours, it took us 5, we were taking it easy but I don't think it would have been possible for us to do it in less than 3 hours unless we did not stop at all. This was strenuous in places if you are not fit, a bit of climbing up and down. They were in the process of installing steps closer to the Manly end when we were there, I'm sure this will help with the muddiness on the trail. If you enjoy walking this is a must do!

A fabulous walk. We did this walk in reverse from Manly to Spit Bridge. We caught the ferry to Manly walked for several hours and then took the bus from the Spit Bridge back into town to get a train home. Beautiful scenary and great excercise.
Man in Harmony with Nature. It is incredible that parts of this walk feel as though you are in wilderness and yet you are in the city.
Grgreat views - one of Sydney's bush highlights. Not especially strenuous and about 2 hours at decent pace Views are great and amazing to think most of it is away from housing Most enjoyable

Stunning views - a great walk!. We caught the bus to Spit Bridge and easily found the start of this walk, which takes you under the bridge and then follows the coastline to Manly. Some of the walk is through the trees, which gives the path more shade (which was welcome as it was a very sunny day). The path was easy to navigate and the views were so pretty! You can take your time, but take lots of water as it was hot. There were so many little spots where we could have stopped to have our picnic - it was hard to choose! We caught the ferry from Manly back to Circular Quay. It was a lovely day out.

Beautiful!!!. Really beautiful walk/hike. Its a 10km walk and they say that it should take around 3-4 hours to walk 1 way, but if you are stoping to take pictures or just to enjoy the nature, it takes way more time. The part from Manly to like Shelly beach was my least favorite as it was just a simple walk next to the ocean, not challenging at all ( i guess nice for families with small kids) and a lot of people around. All the rest of the trail was very nice. You go through Sydney harbour national park exploring wild nature. Part from spit to harbour national park has a bunch of really beautiful beaches. I saw a bunch of birds (like tawny frogmouth owls, penguins), lizards (water dragon) and so on. I really loved it, and it FREE.. ;))

A beautiful walk with amazing views of Sydney harbor, the cityscape and Manly. This is a beautiful walk, with spectacular views including Sydney harbor, Sydney cityscape and Manly itself. The walk takes in a good amount of bush tracks and a few hills in places. It is a must do if you are in Sydney, don't forget to take plenty of sunscreen and water as depending on your speed it may take a couple of hours. I took my 6 year old daughter on this walk and she finished no problem. However, it may not the easiest for people that are less mobile. I would advise getting the bus to the Spit bridge and walking to Manly, this is due to the limited facilities at the Spit Bridge end, finishing in Manly means you have easy access to the Ferries, buses and shops, cafes etc..

A long walk, but a great way to see the area. We picked up a map at the Visitor Centre at Manly quay, then caught a bus to Spit Bridge, and walked back to Manly. It's not a flat, easy walk. There is a bit of scrambling, but nothing overly demanding, and it's a great way to see what the area must have been like before it was developed.

Daily walk . I live by this walk and do it daily. It's a really beautiful way to view this part of the world. Please bear in mind it's not just a stroll. There are some up hill ( and down hill) parts that if you have some walking restrictions wouldn't be suitable.Some spots would be a little roughy or some people. Wear or take a swim suit because along the way are some beautiful quiet little beaches that if you time right you could have all to yourself.Id say if you were a medium to fast pace walker it would take 2 - 2 1/2 hours with no stopping. However if it's your first time you must stop and take in the breathtaking views. Wear a hat, Take water , wear Proper shoes and clothing ( it's dry and sweaty work in summer) have a rucksack. You can do it in joggers, thongs and carry your water and phone if you want but why make life more difficult for yourself.Enjoy! Oh and when you have reached the Manly end its worth bypassing the temptation of the first cafe and do a little extra walk ( 500 yards?!?) to Whistler street to visit Ora for a healthy and delicious smoothie/juice/coffee or breakfast/lunch.

Good varied walk. I have done this walk twice during my visit here, once in each direction. As stated by others, this is a good varied walk on surfaced and unsurfaced paths, in the shade and out in the sun, by the sea and up above the cliffs, flat in places and uphill/downhill in others. The signposting is clearer for the Spit to Manly direction, but if you take the wrong turn while doing Manly to Spit it becomes obvious soon and you can get back on track easily enough. Previous reviewers and other sites state that it is 10 kilometres, but seemed more like 6 to 7 to me

A superb outing. It's a walk. It's a hike. It's a meditation and eye-candy all rolled into one, and you have to work at it (some significant elevation if you do the entire walk. You are richly-rewarded with everything from sweeping views to wildlife (fragile-jawed lizards) to the pleasures of Manley wharf at the end. Do take plenty of water and oranges for quick carbs. You'll need good sun-protection and a hat - you're going to be out there for a few hours. But do not miss this.
Great walk.. Need a couple of hours to enjoy the scenery along the way but the path is well marked out and the walk is very good.

Beautiful and must do in Manly. This walk is a perfect way to explore Manly and it`s finest views. The walk is not that challenging so you don`t need to be very fit for this. I enjoyed this walk and the view and I would do this again if I were in Sydney.
awesome. awesome breath taking views a true gem a must to do if your vist sydney .great tourist spot .ideal for dating or by yourself
Stunning walk. Truly a great walk, amazing places to rest and take in the incredible views. Good for all levels and easy public transport.

Excellent scenic walk from Spit Bridge to Manly. I have been meaning to do The Spit Bridge to Manly Walk for ages and finally managed to do it.Approximately 10km long, it takes around 3 hours to walk it in one direction depending on where you start and how many stops you take.We went on a Sunday and it was pretty hot - about 29 degrees; however there was a nice sea breeze which kept us cool.There were quite a few walkers doing this route in both directions and there are quite a few shady spots which keeps you out of the sun. However make sure you bring sun lotion and plenty of water/food/snacks with you. There are some water fountains along the way and toilets if required though.You also pass a few beaches along the way which is perfect for cooling down in; however as it had been stormy the last few days we didn't go in the water as it says you should not swim due to the pollution. However we did have to take our shoes off near the start as you have to walk in the water along the beach for a bit so make sure you bring a towel to wipe off your feet!As you are following the coast there are many opportunities for fantastic views and you can see the city at some points as well as the Heads. There are some steps up and down so this is not good for prams or wheelchairs. Make sure you have good footwear too. Part of our paths were quite muddy and slippery due to the rain from the days before so be careful.When you get to Manly you can either get a ferry back to the city or a bus back which we did. You can start at either location but I think the way we went was less hilly (don't quote me on that though!).Overall a fantastic walk which you can do quickly or leisurely with lots of stops. There were even a few joggers passing us too.
Easy 10k. The walk will take about 3-4 hours depending on fitness levels. Don't forget water because it is 10km long. If possible go Mon-Fri. Every man and his dog goes on the weekends.

Energetic hike. The walk is hugged along the fore shores of middle harbour to Manly. Some parts you need to go on to the road. You come across a niudist beach if you care to take a dip! Rated medium a few steps at the beginning but relatively easy. When you get to Manly you are welcomed by the many restaurants. I recommend you take a ferry back to circular quay if you are staying in the city. To get to the spit bridge from the city is a simple bus ride.

A Bush Walk Within Sight of the City. An easy walk with some superb scenic views of parts of Sydney Harbour, the Heads and the CBD. Catch a bus from Wynyard, get off after crossing the Spit Bridge, walk along the track until you get to Manly and then catch the ferry back to Circular Quay for a great day out in the open air.
Lovely vista. Friends shared this beautiful view with us. There are so many vantage points in Sydney you don't know where to begin. It's nice having hood friends to share this with you.

Well worth time. This is a 3-4 hour hike make sure you bring water! Then catch the bus across the bridge at spit for ride back to Manly! Great walk if you enjoy hiking ! If your not in shape or have small kids don't do this

Fantastic Walk and the ferry over to Manly is great.. This is a wonderful walk. its about 2-3 hours but with so many small places to swim along the way it could take a lot longer! The views across the bay are just perfect.
Excellent View!. Fantastic view from here. Best if you cycle from below up the hill and then stop to enjoy the view of the cliff.

A walk not to be missed . This walk is one of the greats of Sydney. You can start in manly (easy access via the ferry), however the best is to start off from Spit Bridge. You can get a taxi from manly and then walk back to manly. Or leave your car at spit bridge and then taxi back (it's about $15 max). The walk goes around the headland of the coast, with amazing views of Sydney, aboriginal rock drawings, little creatures and lots more. Stop off for a swim along the way, and don't forget water & sunscreen. There is only one cafe and water spot at the start (from spit bridge) otherwise you're on your own. Enjoy.

A Plesent walk to see the sights of the harbour. You can start at either end them catch a bus back. Take lunch and swimmers with you as there are several spots where you can have a dip. The track is not hard but there are a few spots to be carefull. Keep a lookout for aboriginal rock art and see if you can find the hidden path to Crater Cove in the photo where early huts have been preserved.

Beautiful walk. I took the city bus from downtown Sydney to the bridge. The bus driver was very helpful and let me know where to get off. Quite a change from here in the states! A very long but beautiful walk with some amazing scenery. The walk was nice and quiet as I did not see too many other walkers. The trip does bring you up and down some hills so you certainly want to be in decent shape. The view were spectacular and you get to see a variety of Australia wildlife and vegetation. They even have an area where you can see Aboriginal carvings in the rocks. Made it to Manly and walked around town and walked the beach where I stumbled upon the Shelly Headland Upper Lookout where I watched a beautiful sunset. After a quick bite in town I took the ferry back to Circular Quay. Highly recommend this long trek. Can't beat free views!

FANTASTIC walk. We parked at the Spit, caught a bus to Manly, had a nice coffee and embarked. A group of 10 ! The walk was steady , fantastic views, not overly hard and had heaps of places to stop and have a look. we even had a dip on the way. On reaching the Spit we visited Chiosco Kiosk on the south side of bridge Marina where we had a fantastic lunch. What a day!!

Excellent Walk only if you are fit enough. I've recently completed this walk in a reverse way that is Manly to Spit bridge. Its very scenic all through the way & physically demanding as well. It starts from the sea level but soon take you through ups & downs. Along the path there are many scenic view points that one will definitely enjoy. But be sure to take enough liquid as you will need it & refill point available on the path.

Excellent track along the northern harbour. Not for the unfit, if able to undertake a good 2-3 hour bush walk then this track is worth the effort. lLovely views of unspoilt harbour coastline, not overly busy and good amenities at each end.
Manly Scenic Walkway. This walk is top of the list for Sydney walkers. So beautiful, not too hard, and changing at every turn. A lovely café at North Harbour.

Great day for a 10K. What an incredible day we had. There are so many beautiful views from the waves crashing on the beach or the rocks to the red gum trees and plant and lizard life. Again, a great day for a 10K. Enjoy!

Great views from the other side of the bridge!. Having spent most of my Sydney life in the east or inner west I was coaxed into crossing over the bridge to do the Spit Bridge to Manly Walk. Let's get one thing straight we started in Manly and made our way to the Spit Bridge. Along the way it was a mix of walking along the beach or in the national park. The track is well maintained but I would suggest wearing good walking shoes although some people were wearing thongs/flip flops. The signage along the way explaining various things was also helpful. It was great to see Sydney Harbour from the other side of the bridge. I wasn't disappointed and will definitely return if I have interstate or overseas visitors to show them a different perspective of Sydney.

Challenging walk. We would recommend this walk, we were able to complete the walk in about 3 hours. This is my first time, it is quite a hard walk but challenging with beautiful scenery to see. There are a few spots to rest to enjoy the view. It is recommended to bring water and sunscreen as well.

Good mix of coast, beaches and bush. Nice short hike to 'get away from the city' while staying in the city. The track is well maintained and diverse. There are also plenty of quiet spots to stop by for a rest or just to sit and enjoy the scenery.

Amazing views all round. This walk I can recommend whole hearty. I have complete it many times and can never get enough of the breathtaking views from every vantage point. It is a truly amazing walk you have to do at least once in your life!

Only 30min from CBD, beautiful place to walk. I did this Spit to Manly walk with my travel partner on New Year's Day. We used about 3 hours to get to our final destination, Manly. On the way to there, we found a lot of nice place to swim, do picnic, and stay relax. Also, we enjoyed nice scenery of Sydney city and Manly. The walk path was well maintained, so it was really easy to explore. Just one thing, please don't forget to bring water and sunscreen!

Changing terrain, consistent beauty. This 10km walk was challenging in all the best ways. The path was beautiful the entire way, and kept changing from overlooking the ocean to being in the middle of rainforest. When we were there part of the path was blocked but clearly marked detour got us quickly back on track.

A Very Scenic Walk. This walk is all that you could want from a walk in a major city.......without the feeling of being in a city. The walk goes through everything from urban streets to bush and beaches. Wear walking shoes...take a camera...and take your time...enjoy the fantastic bays and views. We walked from Manly...this way is less steep than the reverse. We finished the walk at Clontarf Reserve with a swim and lunch from 'Clonnys on the Beach'.(Burgers and sandwiches)We then walked to a bus stop at the end of the walk (which is sign posted and easy to find) and caught the bus back to Manly.

The most stunning walk around. Whether you pick this walk up from Clontarf beach or further along there are no prettier views in Sydney. If you're feeling energetic add on the second leg from North Harbour Park to Manly
New Years Day walk. a good 10km walk took 2 hours 20mins..you need to be fit to do it as its quite steep/hilly in places and uneven terrain. fantastic views tho!

Scenic walk well worth doing. We caught a 180 bus from stand C at Wynyard Station in Sydney. Took about 30 minutes to get to the Spit Bridge stop. There are bathrooms there, at Clontarf beach 30 mins in and some more about 30 minutes before manly. Take your own water - there are a couple of places to fill up but these are easy to miss - just pulled sticking up out of the ground - called bubblers. Wear shoes with good tread - there are some slippy areas especially when you start the descent into Manly. Be careful at 40 baskets beach, if the tide is in you have to take a marked detour. Parts of the trail are still a bit muddy after the recent rain, so be prepared to get a bit muddy. Not always well signposted, we had to ask for directions at Clontarf beach after we lost the trail. Lizards were cool! The whole walk took us about 3 hours, ending in Manly with a well deserved lunch at the Bavarian cafe on the ferry wharf before catching the ferry back to circular quay.

Beautiful and a great way to see Sydney. This is a great walk. It is relatively easy on the legs and has breathtaking scenery and views along the way. If you're up for it there is also some awesome swimming spots on the way.

Long but the views are so worth it.. We have done this walk 3 times in the last few years. Each time it is different depending on the weather. Last weekend we embarked on it for the 3rd time. Caught a bus from Central station to the Spit and began the walk. Were fortunate enough to see the Spit Bridge open so that was a great start. The begining of the walk is probably the hardest. More bush tracks and more ups and downs. By the time you get to near Manly, it is pathways which is a great way to end it off. The views along the way are magnificent and the sea breezes keep you cool. Plenty of places to stop for rests on the way or a splash in the ocean but no shops really to purchase drinks or food. It is a 3 hour walk so wear comfy shoes but it is a doable walk for people of all fitness levels; simply go at your own pace. We have done it with young Primary age children, with teens and this time, just my husband and I. Once you arrive at Manly, you can then reward yourself with a delicious fish and chip meal. You could even end the walk off with a visit to the Aqarium which is really worthwhile. We love this walk and if we lived closer, would do it many more times but we live an hour and half drive away. However, we reckon it is worth the drive to see those amazing views.

Tough but worth it. Took a bus to The Spit and then started on the walk. It's a long walk so wear comfortable walking shoes. Lots of steps, uneven in places and going through vegetation so more enclosed in places so not for people with mobility issues. Some lovely views but pleased to arrive in Manly. We took the ferry back to Sydney.

Must do scenic walk. This is 10 km of Sydney's foreshore you simply must see. We were dropped at the Spit Bridge by friends and capped off our experience with the also must do Manly Ferry ride back to Circular Quay. You could also park your car at the Spit and return by bus from Manly. The walk is not easy, lots of stairs meandering up and down but the views along the way are worth it all, it's so pretty you marvel you are in a capital city at all. The walk crosses local beaches and in places you must walk the sand and risk getting wet feet ( all part of the fun) there is shade a lot of the way, but as you come up over the headland and start getting those wonderful views out to North and South Head and Manly too you are quite exposed to sun and wind, hats necessary, some wonderful Indigenous Rock Art also on the headland , don't miss the slight detour to take that in.
Plenty of wildlife. Some great views of different areas of Sydney harbour, you will require a reasonable level of fitness, as it is a 3 hour walk with plenty of stairs

Need some exercise in an out door and beautiful environment?. Never more than metres from a clean deep water harbour, many places to sit and picnic, perspectives across the water, and native bushland to your back. Take sun protection, water and walker footwear. Reach Manly and ferry return to the city.

Great walk with fantastic views. Highly recommend this walk! Aprox 3 hours but you will want to stop off to admire views/swim! Walk through some really fancy houses in Manly first and then through the bush. Amazing on a blue sky day!

Brilliant walk...amazing views. The Spit to Manly walk along with the Bondi to Coogee walk is considered among the best walks around Sydney. The Spit to Manly walk takes about 4-5 hours to cover the 10 kms of walk through a multitude of beaches, vantage points, hillsides. It starts from the Spit bridge (if you are travelling by bus, get down immediately after the Spit bridge and look out for signage indicating the start of the walk) and ends at the Manly wharf. A few pointers:1.) Carry a water bottle (and some snacks) as it is a long walk 2.) Carry a camera is possible as you will get some amazing views on the way3.) Food and water is available at select places only (Clontarf Reserve at the start of the walk has an eatery - you can grab a bite here if needed)4.) Look out for side roads moving away from the main route - these are very rewarding with fantastic views of the seas, cliffs and even the cityscapes. There are a few aboriginal carvings as well at a location. So take your time and allot at least half a day to savor the most from this walk5.) You will find a few good beaches as well, including a few reef spots for snorkelling - carry your gear in case you feel it interesting6.) There are markers / signs all along the way with maps of the vantage points / points of interest - do check them to ensure you know which ones to pick (check image)Lastly, once you reach Manly, there are multiple restaurants to help you with a well deseved meal to regain a few of the calories lost

Amazing Walk. This is a must do when visiting Sydney. It is a 10 km walk. We started at Spit Bridge and walked all the way to Manly. The views are spectacular. The walk is a medium level walk with some steep stairs and gravel in places. But it is fantastic. The homes on the beach along the way and the Barbour views are breathtaking. A must do in Sydney..

Leisurely stroll to jolly jog. This walk is a stunner. Gentle enough for the uninitiated walkers and ling enough for the athlete. Stunning scenery, we took some snacks and a salad, which kept us going. We swam at end o ease those sore feet. Wonderful, a must do for Sydney siders. So much chill within close proximity to the city centre. U

A perfect way to see the best Harbour in the World. We hiked the spit to manly walk just after Christmas. Didn't start at the spit bridge, but halfway from Tania Park. We walked the track along the headland, which has spectacular views of the harbour. mostly downhill then flat as you pass by Reef Beach and 40 baskets beach. The track is well worn and easy to follow. Finished up at Manly Beach and had some delicious fish and chips, but watch for the seagulls. they like to snatch the food from your hand if not careful. An ice cream on the way back and then did the walk back along the track to the car. Last part climbing back up to the park is a bit steep, wear good footwear, and watch out for stupid people who like to think they are doing the amazing race. Take time to rest and enjoy. BTW it's free

Must do. Really enjoyed this stunning walk between Spit and Manly, although must say we enjoyed the first half (closer to Spit) more. It is very beautiful and a mix of forest and stunning water views with turquoise waters. Make sure to take water and sunscreen!
Best walking trail!. Another must to do in Sydney I would highly recommend! It's a little bit long but easy to exist when you tired half way, you will see so many hidden beaches!

A truly spectacular walk with unsurpassed view of the harbor. This is my favored walk in Sydney and I have done it a dozen times. I usually take the ferry to Manly and I walk from there to the Spit in about 3 hours to take a bus or a taxi back to Sydney. The walk starts at the ferry terminal and it easy to follow: just keep the water on your left all the times. It passes Manly, many coves where you can swim, and it climbs a bit before following again the harbor through many others coves. The view of Manly, the Heads, the harbor and Sydney are just spectacular. It is an easy trail but you should consider wearing good shoes and carrying water.

One of the Best walks in Sydney. One of the best walks in Sydney . A total of 2 hours would be convenient . The walk starts at Spit bridge in Mosman which can be conveniently reached from City in a public Bus.The geography varies which makes the walk look very beautiful . Since it is a coastal walk there are food options available in every 30mins at least . We did the walk during spring season and hence could locate a lot of beautiful flowers . Carry a lot of water . Preferably avoid the walk during noon as summer heat can get pretty bad . Would be good to start in the afternoon if during summer or in the morning if in winter . There is no cost associated with it . At the end of the walk in Manly , there is Bavarian Cafe which is great for a drink before heading back to Circular Quay in a ferry.
Lovely Walk, very enjoyable. The walk Spit Bridge to Manly, such a enjoyable walk so worth doing. Beautiful views.On a nice sunny day it is well worth a nice stroll.

Amazing views of Sydney. This is a must do for locals and visitors! Wear good shoes and carry water and snacks for your walk and enjoy the amazing views! it's a long walk and at times it can be quite challenging going up and down stairs depending on your fitness level. Take some swimmers if you want to take a swim as there are lots of quiet beaches along the way.

Great walk. Love this walk make sure you have food to eat and drinks as not much on way plenty of scenery of the harbour, takes approx 2-3 hours and more if you stop a lot , if hot take swimmers plenty stops to have a swim.

Thoroughly enjoyable. Enjoyed every bit of this amazing walk! The views, the variety of plant and birdlife - it ticks all the boxes for a great way to spend a day. A must-do for any keen walkers visiting Sydney. Finished off with a cold drink (or two) at Manley before catching the Ferry back to Circular Quay.

Great walk, up and down, but changes throughout well worth it. Take the Manly ferry and you will need to get to the start at Spit Bridge (friends drove us). Best to go in this direction. Ideally use trainers at least, the walk is up and down a lot, so you need to be fit. It is basic, no coffee shops, so take your own food and refreshment. The scenery is stunning, you see large lizards in the bush towards Spit Bridge end, the last aboriginal art still in its original place at the top of the walk, ideal for a break. Manly end is a welcome sight for a beer and a snack. well worth it and free.

Magnificent Walk. A long but satisfying walk that will show case some spectacular scenery around Sydney Harbour. Must take water and good hiking shoes. End up in Manly and have a drink and meal at one of the great restaurants.

A must do !. Whether you are a tourist or a local , this has to be on your "must do " list. It's not a short walk though, so be warned. It will take you a good 3 hours at least , especially if you stop for a swim at the secluded beaches along the way. We often cut it short by parking at Clontarf reserve, and starting the walk from there. I have never done it both ways , we usually get a bus/taxi/uber back to the car.One of the best walks in Sydney , especially in summer .Highly recommended.
Bushwalking close to the city. Good exercise, beautiful sights, Aboriginal carvings, and stop at Manly Beach for a nice lunch and a cold one at the end.
Spectacular. I have done this hike several times now and every time I am awed by the scenery. Nice secluded spots to stop for a picnic or a swim and to take spectacular photos.
The best view of Sydney harbour from the North. I am sure there are reams and reams of reviews for this but whether you live in Sydney or come for a visit this is one of Sydney's great walks.
excellent. i have driven and been at both at these places. it's mesmerizing. but have not done the whole walk. suffered depression but the spit bridge is amazing that area. really is.

fantastic walk. Definitely a must do walk if in Sydney.
Plenty of nice spots to for photos and lots of places to stop for a swim on a hot day.
Easy access by public transport to starting or finishing points.

A must do for anyone visiting Sydney. The best things in life are free. This walk is one Sydney's highlights. Take you time and take your swimmers. Enjoy a drink and a feed at the Manly wharf before catching the ferry back to the CBD

Great walk. We walked from Manly to Spit Bridge and then got the bus back. We picked up a map from the visitor centre in Manly which was useful at a couple of points so we could be sure we'd gone the right way. The walk was largely sign-posted clearly, the only issue we had with directions was that almost at the end when you get to the beach, there's just a vague indication that you have to walk the length of the beach, but we couldn't as the sea was all the way in at one point. Thankfully we could navigate our way to the far end on the side-roads behind the beach.Also, there was meant to be a coffee shop about two-thirds of the way along, but we didn't even notice a sign for it. Then not long before the end of the walk at the beach there is a shop and cafe you can't miss.There are a couple of stopping points with water taps/fountains and toilets directly off the walk, it wasn't too hot the day we were there and we found a litre of water each was enough between refills. Probably worth having more than that and taking snacks if you think you're not going to walk very fast.The walk took around 4hrs, with us walking at a fairly quick pace but stopping for photos / drinks / suntan-lotion application now and then. A lot of the walk is quite shady, but you do definitely need hat / sunglasses / suntan-lotion. There are a lot of steps, both up and down, as you go along the coast popping down to the shore one moment then back up along a cliff edge the next. The difficulty is probably a medium level, most people could manage it but some might need to go slower. There were people jogging/running some sections though!The views are great and the whole walk is very scenic. Highly recommended.

One of my favorite walks in Sydney!. Pick a nice weather day to go, and you will be sure to LOVE this walk. The views are, as always, spectacular, and the trail is perfect for people of all fitness types. You can turn it into a gorgeous run, or take a slow stroll and enjoy the scenery. Either way, you can't beat the beauty of nature! The walk will definitely take a long chunk of time - but that depends on how quickly you walk!

One of my favourite walks - a nice longer walk than the usual tourist routes. I love this walk and regularly take the trip over to do it (we're in training for a 100km hike).
