I think it is better to start at Spit Bridge and walk to Manly as opposed to the other way around as transport links from Manly are better, plus its a nicer place to finish up (there's not much at Spit Bridge - there is a nice Italian restaurant though with some delicious gnocchi).The start of the walk is tricky to find so follow these simple steps:  If taking the bus from the city, alight at bus stop and cross to the opposite side of the road (use the pedestrian crossing just behind you). Now continue the direction the bus was going and walk across the bridge. On your right hand side once you have crossed the bridge you will see an unnamed road (car accessible), walk down here and you will see the signposts for the beginning of the walk. The walk itself has some steep climbs, steps and mixed terrain (beach, bush etc.) so I wouldn't take my grandmother. I would say anyone of any fitness level could do the walk, but you might need to take it slower. I am a quick, energetic walker, many a time I have more then a bead of sweat at the top of one of the hills, especially in hot weather.Take suncream! There are some water fountains en-route, so refilling isn't too much of an issue. The time it takes to complete the walk really varies on fitness level, photo taking etc. When I've taken guests, it has taken up to 4-hours, when I went solo it took 2-hours, 8-minutes the last time (to be precise).The views are amazing, the animals (lizards and birds) en-route are awesome, and it is just truly a fantastic walk! Wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to others!

One of the best walks in Sydney--a bit tiring. My daughter was studying here and took me on this walk--so beautiful--tiny isolated harbours, beautiful sailboats, Aboriginal rock carvings, calm lizards...probably good to bring some gatorade and comfy sneakers...

Great day out. We were recommended this walk by family living in the area. So, a trip to Sydney would not be the same without trying it out. And it was worth the hike. Gorgeous scenery, lots of wild life, and a bit of history in between. Would recommend to pack a rucksack with some water and perhaps food. And if you fancy a swim, bring your bathing suits and towels. There are some beached on the way where you can cool down with a swim.Arriving in Manley, you can find a local bar to enjoy a cold beverage, or find a place to get a cooling ice cream. Would definitely do this walk again
Walked it backwards. We thoroughly recommend this delightful walk for the stunning vistas, Aboriginal carvings, variety of footpaths from sandy to steep to wide to narrow to boradwalks etc
Prettiest views of Sydney. 10k of amazing views along cliffs and beaches. Not as crowded as the Bondi to Coogee walk and trails are more challenging.

A beautiful coastal harbour walk. If you are looking for a brisk 3 hour walk, take a trip from Spit Bridge and follow the walk all the way to Manly - takes about three hours, you can walk, run or just do part of it. Catch a bus or taxi back to Spit if you have parked your car, otherwise continue on the bus to your destination

Rewarding hike! . Your legs are going to be hurting for days but it is so rewarding!!! There are so many magnificent look outs throughout this walk. Parts can be challenging if you are not fit or used to walking up hill for a long period of time. This is definitely NOT an easy walk! If you would like an easy walk then take the ferry to and from manly and just walk as much as you feel comfortable with and turn around. That being said, the truly beautiful spots are up high and therefore you have to work for them. I would recommend this to anyone going to Sydney but be warned that it is challenging!

A good morning's walk. This is a longer walk packed with superb views of the inner Harbour and Sydney Heads. On a sunny day this is a great activity. You can take a picnic as there are plenty of places to stop and enjoy the splendid views. You can go in either direction starting an The Spit Bridge or Manly. Unless you do the return journey on foot you will need to use public buses to make the trip.

Beautriful views. There are some fairly steep ups and downs on the walk, but take your time and it is well worth it as there are magnificent views of the harbour and the City of Sydney. Be prepared to carry water, especially in the summer as there is little in he way of cafes or shops.

Great walk, varied conditions, gorgeous views. Love coastal treks and the Spit Bridge to Manly walk will not let you down. Trek along the shore of inland tributary towards Sydney Harbour and along towards Manly. There are bushy, woodsy areas, wooden tracks, stones to fossick, beaches to stroll, and some of the finest vistas around Sydney. I highly recommend the trek for the natural experience alone... yet when reaching Manly, we often enjoy a cafe meal, drink, then board the Ferry back to the City. What better? Top off the day with a harbour cruise (on one of the many ferries) for just a few dollars -- enjoy!

another brilliant Sydney walk. This walk can be accessed by catching the Ferry to Manly. walking to the left after you come off the wharf and following the harbour around. A spectacular walk that starts off walking through suburbs on the harbout but you end up in bushland with spectacular views of the harbour. you can walk all the way to the Spit Bridge - make your way up onto the main road and catch a bus back into the city.Be sure to take water and food as there are no food or drink stops on this walk.This walk would take up most of your day especially if you were going both ways in and back.Lots of wildlife and birds to see .get to see some wonderful bush huts that some lucky people get to live in.but best of all are the views of the heads, the Sydney skyline and the action on the harbour.Great place to go on boxing day - find a spot and watch the Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race head off through the heads.

Fabulous walk!. We have done this walk a few times, the latest being this week. Go on a sunny day, track can be very wet in parts if there has been a lot of rain. Wear good walking shoes, walk takes between 2-3 hours and take plenty of water, hat & jacket if necessary. Catch one of the buses from Military Road (we got 143 and got off BEFORE the Spit bridge near the restaurants at the bottom of the hill) Walk to the right hand side of the bridge and the track starts from there around the beach. Keep to the coastline, there are a couple of spots that go inland on the streets but you should find yourself back on the coast to walk into Manly. Great day out!

Breathtaking views. This was probably the most beautiful thing we did. The walk is so lovely with fantastic views all the way to Manly. Have lunch in the restaurant next to the ferry, $10 steak and ferry back to Sydney, ending up with a cocktail in the Opera Bar. Perfect day in Sydney

An absolute must for visitors who love to walk. One of the most beautiful walks in a capital city anywhere in the world. I have travelled a lot and walked in many countries. Whilst I may appear biased, this is without a doubt one of the most beautiful walks I have done. A must for visitors who love to walk!

Sensational walk with panoramic views. This is the quintessential Sydney walk! It includes magnificent views of the Spit, the Harbour and Sydney Heads, a range of different types of bushland, birds and lizards, beach and foreshore walks, both large and small hidden beaches for swimming and many spots to stop and admire the beauty of Sydney or for a picnic.The walk is well maintained and clearly signposted and generally of easy grade although there are some steep pinches. There is no water along the walk so it is essential to carry some and the walk is best done in Spring or Autumn or early in the morning.The destination, Manly, is full of great shops, cafes and restaurants and Manly Beach is superb and a worthy end to what is undoubtably one of the most scenic walks in Australia.

One of the best walks you will ever take. Stunning harbour views, bush land with a variety of flora and fauna, beautiful hidden beaches and at the end Manly, and everything it has to offer. Wear good shoes and take water and an apple, be prepared for some climbing ....you'll love it!!!

Views, beaches, rich flora and great smiles on the way!!. After having done so many bushwalks, in Sydney, Vancouver and India, I had doubts that this walk will standout, but it did. The walk is done mostly by the strong hearted, so you wont find it crowded. The perfect months are Nov and Feb. I parked my car near spit bridge (look for free parking in the residential area) and started my walk. If you are scared of water dragons, first 2 km may be difficult but after that is all paradise. A few cafes on the way. Carry a change if you plan to take a dip in the beautiful water on the way. You may want to go up further from manly to North Head for beautiful views of the sydney skyline. And the cafe at north fort is byfar my favourite in sydney!!
Do it!. Fab way to appreciate this amazing city. Wear comfy trainers, and be prepared for lots of steps! The routs is mainly excellently maintained, and provides one breathtaking view after another!,

superb views and well kept walk. Four of us seniors went awalking on a hot steamy day from Manly to the Spit Bridge. We didn't quite finish the walk, but we really enjoyed what we did. Lots of birds and great wildflowers blooming at this time of year, and of course, the views are amazing. We exited at Grotto Point, and to our astonishment, found a free bus at the exit point to take us to Ballgowlah shopping centre and another back to Manly ferry. Before you leave the ferry terminal, go to the information centre there and pick up a free brochure listing the buses and their routes. It's worthwhile having the buses as back up in case you hit a bad day as we did. The bus drivers are very helpful. At Grotto point the buses seem to come at a quarter to the hour, and not sure of other times. We will take the bus there the next time to finish the walk. We caught the ferry from Circular Quay, returning later in the day on the same ferry. Nice cafes at Manly for lunch or coffee and cake.

An absolute must of you enjoy walking and great scenery !. Amazing walk through the "bush" with an abundance of scenic views. The route is not as "open" as we expected in as much as the views are hidden by the bush but this adds to the attraction as every now and then when you least expect it a gap appears and you're presented with another stunning view of the coastline, or one of the many coves. It does involve a lot of climbing and descending the pathway which has been caringly looked after by a team of volunteers and on a warm day can be tiring. As another reviewer said "dress appropriately and carry plenty of water" We didn't carry our lunch but opted for the end of walk cold beer and food at manly wharf - excellent!

One of the great walks in the world. We have done many short walks in the world and this would rate highly. A great way to see another part of Sydney and see many aspects, from the Heads to the nature reserves and the beaches at Manly or the Spit. Not too difficult.

Only way to enjoy best view of the Harbour. Want to breathe in the spectacular harbour then put on your walking boots. Do it because it's healthy fun and eye candy. Take your lunch pack or treat yourself at the end at Manley wharf .

See the bush without leaving Sydney . We did the walk from Manly to Spit Bridge. The walk was incredibly scenic with constant harbour views, lots of little coves and an extended walk through bushland. It was well signposted and there were so many tourists about you really couldn't get lost. But remember it is a long walk (10km) with lots of going up and down. There is no water to be had for most of the walk. On warmer days the walk can get hot and stifling. So dress appropriately and take plenty of water. The highlight for us was going down to one of the little coves and soaking our, by then, aching feet in the cool waters. Just heaven.

Scared of heights don't worry so was I . OMG Safety Safety Safety all the way,Don't worry about a thing it's all covered, But No Phones Camara's, No watches earnings or bangles, and you have to clear a metal detector before you go up so don't even think about it.Top tips, Do not take to much with you everything goes in a secure locker and you wear the key around you neck 100% secure, you'll strip to your underwear if it's hot weather they give you a very trendy onesie or jump suit clean and fresh. Then you go through a safety briefing and knitted out with everything from headphones to hankies to mop your sweat. Safety harness and elasticated strap for sunglasses. The walk is well managed and there are drink fountains and mist fans on the bridge they even have a doctor / medic up on the bridge. It's totally all covered even for the nervous such as myself. But I was buzzing the guides were great the history and geographical information was superb, we did the 3.5 hr climb at twilight which means you see the city by day then the sun set then come down in the dark but don't worry you get a torch to wear on your head not that you really need it but it look cool.We cannot sing the praise of these guys and girls and the organisation enough it's not cheap but neither is the flight to Aus so once in a lifetime go for it at the end you get a free cap and then you need to purchase your pictures these are taken by your guide up on the top of the bridge and are well worth the little extra

Great Walk with stunning views. Truly great walk if you have the time - It will take a few hours. Best done by parking a car at the beginning and end of the walk, but can be done with public transport. Walking from the Spit and finishing at Manly is the best way to do it - easier walk and more food options at the end.
Both locals and tourists love this walk!. Good spot to go for a walk to a run with breathtaking views. The locals loves their walk and tourists do to. Can't wait until I'm able to go back!

Great walk with stunning views. This is a great walk with stunning views. The path is easy to follow and has several stop/ picnic points along the way. There are a number of steps involved but being a coastal walk this is to be expected. Allow 3 hours to complete including a break. Well worth making the effort. Catch a bus from across the Spit bridge back into Sydney

Excellent walk full of great views and some surprises. We took 3 hours to complete this walk but could easily have done it in under 2. We were lucky with the tides and were able to take several short cuts across various beaches. Because it was spring, the wildflowers were in full bloom in the national park around Grotto Point. We swam at Castle Rock in crystal clear water. The only unpleasant part was having to walk along the crowded public beach at Clontarf. If finishing at Spit Bridge, make sure to do your research on how to get public transport back to Manly or Sydney. The signage is very poor and not clear on where to go. We were lucky that a sympathetic bus driver helped us out.

One to put on your 'to do' list. A lovely walk with fantastic views over Sydney Harbour. Admire some remarkable architecture at the Spit Bridge-Clontarf end as you walk the beach and bush track, then immerse yourself in nature as you cross the headland. Spot the old squatters huts on the cliff edge from the Depression days, and have a swim at one of the many coves along the way. The wild flowers are in bloom and it was a truly gorgeous day. Busses connect easily in either direction.

A long worthwhile walk. This is a long walk, but well worth the effort with a mix of some spectacular views across the harbour and bush walking, albeit on duck boards. It can be hot so you need to take plenty of water with you.

Lovely walk. A nice walk. With wonderful views of harbour. A little hard going for the unfit like me but well worth it. Make sure you get off the buss before it crosses spit bridge as its difficult to cross road afterwards (that's if you come form City)

Wonderful intro to bushwalking. This track is an excellent way to turn someone on to bushwalking. First, make sure it is a nice day, not too hot or humid and definitely not when its raining. And carry water, even in the cooler months. Spring is perfect - when the wattles and wildflowers are in full bloom and the track is a blaze of colour. And the views over the bush and the harbour, back to the city and across Manly Cove are stupendous. If for some rare reason the person doesn't enjoy the experience, you can reassure yourself that you have tried your best and they are just not the bushwalking type.The track is about 10 km long and takes about two and a half hours to walk. Most of the track is well made, though there are a couple of steep bits and it does get muddy and in places slippery after rain. Get to either end of the track by public transport - bus from Wynyard Station to the Spit or ferry to Manly. The kiosk at Clontarf Park is only about half an hour from the Spit and is an excellent place to stop for a coffee. In fact, it is the only such stop along the route.
Beautiful walk. Very beautiful walk - but it takes 4-5 hours to complete. It is up and down a lot, but there is many great viewpoints.
Spectacular scenery. This a fantastic walk on a beautiful spring day. Please do not do it in a tour group, enjoy it with a friend.

Spectacular views and a bit of a challenge. The Spit to Manly walk is spectacular! You will see Sydney Harbour from one of its most beautiful sides, plus you'll get a great work-out.You need to be reasonably fit to take on this walk, there's a lot of steep hills and stairs, prepare to sweat. Make sure to bring lots of water, sunscreen and maybe even a snack if going in summer.I like walking from the Spit Bridge to Manly (some people prefer the other way), so that I can have a coffee, lunch or something in Manly when I finish the walk.

Lots and lots of steps. What a great walk, and hard to get lost. I walked from manly to spit and then picked up the bus back into town. A stunning walk, especially once you get away from habitation and into the coastal bush. There are a lot of steps, my iPhone reckoned I did 50 flights of stairs today!!! Other than that a fairly easy walk for all ages and abilities.

Must do activity if you live in or are visiting Sydney. Excellent walk with spectacular views. Not difficult and has public transport options at both ends. manly has lot of food and drink options upon finishing.
Great views. Great walk along the coast through Sydney Harbour National Park and a few beautiful neighbourhoods. Amazing views and very peaceful. Definitely a highlight of my times in Sydney.
A great morning trip.. Sydney is spoilt for great coastal walks, but this was fantastic. Well signposted, good for beginners. You end up in Manly, a great place for lunch or to chill on the beach

One of Our Most Memorable Hikes!!. On a gorgeous day in early September, we walked a block from our hotel in Sydney's CBD and caught the bus which stops on the far side of The Spit bridge across Fisher Bay. Since it was Sunday, we had purchased "Sunday-Funday" tickets for AUD2.50 each, which allowed us to travel by metro, bus and ferry, all day long, a super bargain.Alighting at The Spit, we took the trail which goes under the bridge and heads around Fisher Bay, then on to Sandy Bay Road to Clontarf Beach. On a Sunday morning, this lovely area was chock full of families, kids everywhere, barbies roaring, dogs splashing in the bay, fun everywhere. The walk continues along the shore and headlands of the Middle Harbor, then moves inland as the trail turns to the northeast. There is a lot of up-and-down walking, many sets of stairs, some boardwalks, but mostly just track. The way is mostly smooth walking. And it is absolutely spectacular! From each high point, a lovely vista opens up -- marinas, gorgeous clear water trending from turquoise to deep blue, a few whitecaps showing, sailboats underway, ferries passing. And then the view from the next headland is even more stunning. On a Sunday you will encounter hundreds of hikers, going in both directions, but the trail and the topography easily absorb all comers. From Crater Cove around Dobroyd Head to Reef Beach and on past the residences of Forth Baskets Beach and around the North Harbor, the trail takes you from one breathtaking site to the next. It's a ten km hike from The Spit bridge, and one you will remember.Once you arrive in Manly, the crowds really take over on a Sunday morning. There are folks everywhere, milling about, filling all the cafes and shops, ambling along the Corso over to the Pacific side, then filling the beach over there as well. So just be ready to "go with the flow" until you find a nice spot to stop, have a beer or eat lunch.We chose the Hotel Steyne's spacious restaurant, grabbed a table overlooking the action on the beach and had some excellent fish 'n chips, with a very nice local lager to wash it all down.Then off to the ferry back to Circular Quay, where we immediately hopped (for free) onto another ferry out to Watson's Bay and back for a different perspective on this magnificent harbor.

Beautiful!. An amazing walk you have to do when visiting Sydney. Less crowded than the Bondi to Coogee walk but it is so amazing and you get to some really good look out points where you can take great photos. Try to look up where to go before doing the actual walk, we got lost a couple of times.
Lovely afternoon. rented bikes and did many to spit on a gloriously sunny day, what's not to love. You can get a nice fish and chips when you get to the spit bridge at the cafe with a beach.

A snake or a lizard?. We started from the spit end after getting the bus from Wynyard Station. We found the first hour of the walk to be really spectacular, however that was the best bit. There after it was still not but just not as breathtaking. We saw a lizard along the way too, which looked very much like a snake...took about 3hrs to do the walk!

Spit to Manly Super walk. This is a great walk. As an aside, take the turnoff to the right at the bottom of the path which comes down from the Dobroyd Park and go along to the old fishermans' huts. Pure magic and lots of waterdragons.

Beautiful walk. This is one of the most picturesque hikes you can do. You are walking along the coast - mostly in the shade looking out onto Sydney Harbour. You can have lunch in Manly and turn around and go back or catch a taxi to where you parked the car.

Good views, varied walk, not a bush track anymore.. I often used to walk this track more than twice a month, usually from 7am on Sunday mornings. At that time it is cooler and you avoid most of the earnest latex clad runners pushing past. It is a most scenic, interesting, varied path, and quite challenging as it is 9.5 km each way and rises up to 200ft above sea level before descending again to the beaches. There is an interesting midden made from shells discarded by aborigines years ago, and many birds and usually large lizards to be seen up close. We used to breakfast near the wharf in Manly and walk back again, enjoying its unspoiled natural state clambering over rocks and by-passing rain puddles. However , some five years or so ago the authorities started “ improvements” (Schlimmbesserung) by bringing in great sacks of gravel (by helicopter I'm told) to widen and line paths, handrails have been added and I believe steps installed in some places. We don’t go there anymore. These works may help some less fit people and others but spoil the experience for many more. I accept that, at my age, I cannot climb Mt Everest now but I don’t want a lift installed for people who can’t do it.

Beautiful views. We began this walk at Manly which you can do at your own pace -there were some people running while others were riding or walking. The view along the way is just gorgeous. Walking with the sea on one side and views of Manly on the other is a relaxing way to spend a day. This is a popular walk and the path does get busy at times. Lots of places to stop and sit of just take a photo. If you are looking for something to do when visiting Manly other than swimming at the beach I recommend you do this walk or even part of the walk.

Much loved walk. We used to do this all the time when we lived in Sydney, and it continues to be a must do whenever we are in town. We go early to avoid the hordes (which is getting harder to do these days) and stretches through the National Park have been vastly improved over the years. My husband starts in North Sydney, and I drive to Manly. We cross over somewhere near the oval so husband continues to Manly while I actually exit at Balgowlah Heights to get a coffee at the fab deli at the top of the hill, and wait to be picked up. The beauty of the walk is the different "worlds" you go through - by the harbour with all the locals exercising their dogs, a few suburban streets, the Harbourside parks, the bush of the national park, and of course the stunning views of the Heads. Whichever variation of the walk, it is a winner, and of course the benefit of doing whole Spit to Manly is that you can have brekkie at one of Manlys terrific cafes.
Spit to Manly Walk - take the time to enjoy!. Just finished this wonderful walk today! Stunning views. Bush, beaches and parks. 10km. Medium fitness required. Lots of stairs, but so worth the effort!
Sydney's hidden beauty. magic views and not as crowded as some other wlaks. Avoid Dec and Jan as it is hot - take water. great way to burn a few calories
Beautiful Scenery. Beautiful scenic walk, stunning beaches to stop off at for a cool down dip. Looking forward to walk this in summer to enjoy a swim

Enjoyable walk for an afternoon. A nice walk although the path isn't overly clear in a lot of places and went off course a few times. There is a point where you can choose to stay more rural or finish on the street which is quicker and easier if you have less able people. Some parts are quite closed over so although still enjoyable you don't get vews 100% of the way around. It's reasonably lengthy for normal folk (wranglers wouldn't bat an eyelid) so allow a ood 1.5hrs for a casual stroll. Not many places to get refreshments though so bring drinks with you.
Gorgeous. Great way to spend a sunny day in Sydney - gorgeous views, gentle walk, perfect taste of Sydney and all it has to offer...

You can't go wrong. I've done the walk a few times and going again this Saturday with the kids. Absolutely fabulous each time. Best with friends and/or family. Bring a good camera along and make sure to stop and take in the views. Marvelous all around. Check the weather forecast as it is a bit of a walk and you can't just turn back if inclement weather hits. Offers various terrain and breath-taking views. Manly beckons at the end and a cold one is just irresistible.

Great walk, and probably longer than you think!!. It's a good long wak so be prepared. (Some weren't prepared for the long walk and were struggling.)If you can leave a car at one end to make it easy to get back.Also great to finish in Manly and then go grab a beer, or some food.

Great Views. This 10K walk is pretty tough going as there are a lot of ups and downs but it definitely worth it. The views are amazing. However, we went when it was quite cool. So I would definitely advise doing it during the hottest part of the day. Bring lots of water!

The best walk in Sydney. One of the nicest walk you can take in Sydney.
Offering stunning views, reinvigorating fresh air and recharging calm!

Another excellent walk. This is a fantastic walk but be warned it is quite touch, there are tons of stairs but everyone time you reach the top of a climb you are rewarded with an amazing view. We used the Wildwalks app and found a circuit route from Spit bridge to North Harbour reserve and back to our car.
Worth a walk. There are two must do walks in Sydney. Coogee to Bondi & Spit to Manly. A great bush walk over looking the Harbour. Spectacular views, take a bottle of water and wear good shoes.

Great experience. What a great walk with excellent harbour views and varying track types. Walked Manly to The Spit and then back to Manly. Bit footsore but a great challenge and experience. Suggest avoid walking at high tide near Clontarf beachfront homes although there is an alternative high tide route. In summer you may see water dragons on the track around the small bays close to the The Spit end of the track.

Perfect bushwalk right in the CBD, less crowds. If you only have time to do one Sydney walk, do this one. It's slightly odd to get to, you need to look up bus routes/ get a taxi to drop you. But that makes it all the more worthwhile, it's a bushwalk in the centre of Sydney that you should start mid-afternoon, then take the Manly ferry back to the CBD to catch the coathanger (Sydney Harbour Bridge) in the sunset

Scenic walk. We did most if this walk as part of our visit to Manly, the 1st part was really easy, this for steeper after around 3.5Km. This is really worthwhile and we would of loved to have finished this however we ran out of time. The weather was glorious even though it was August just perfect for a walk. It was good to find clean toilets along the way. The walk mostly followed the cost, and was frequently on clearly defined paths. This is a beautiful walk, very enjoyable.

Decent walk - not too strenuous. This is a lovely walk, and you can easily do it from a bus ride from the city, and end up with a ferry ride back form Manly to the city.there are parts of the walk where you need to walk along uneven pathways, rocks or on sand - so you need a reasonable level of fitness and mobility.I'd give yourself 2-3 hours to complete the walk. and PLENTY of sunscreen - with the wind you may not notice how much sun you're getting!
Definitely do this walk - a lovely different way to see the Harbour. A wonderful, easy walk skirting the edge of Middle Harbour around to Manly with great views at every turn.
Holiday walkabout . Fabulous walk with brilliant views.Some steps, slopes and beach sections with beautiful shells and more views. Definitely worth the walk

Great Hike. We took the ferry to Manly and started at the ferry station. GET A MAP as some of the area marking are not clear. There is an option to go through a neighborhood or the woodland area....pick the woodland. We say so many beautiful birds (cockatoo, rainbow colored parrots).Hiked with kids 14 and 10. Bring good shoes (hikers or tennis shoes). There are some more challenging areas. Took us a little under 3 hours. You can get a taxi or bus at the Spit Bridge area.After the hike we told a taxi back to the ferry station and walked to Manly beach.

Sidney from the other side.. Beautiful but it now has many steps with no railings. Take walking sticks. You can take a bus which goes over the bridge, down to the Spit. Allow plenty of time: the bus ride lasts about 30 minutes or more. Before going into Manlly, you can stop at a beautiful sandy beach and spend some time there.

Even if you only have two days in Sydney, this is worth doing.. Being a local, I've done this walk many times. I've done it from The Spit Bridge to Manly and also in reverse. I've also run it when training for a race. It's approximately 9kms one way. About a month ago we did it there and back so 18kms of walking. It's up and down so don't think it's an easy stroll but then of course it's also not like walking in the Dolomites where uphill really does mean uphill! Take a snack as there are numerous places to stop and sit and look at one of the most beautiful harbours in the world. And take water especially if it is hot.You could do the walk in standard running shoes or sneakers. If you end up in Manly then you're spoilt for choice in terms of cafes and restaurants. However, if you finish at the Spit Bridge then there are really only expensive restaurants to choose from. If you park your car at The Spit Bridge (time limits apply so be careful of parking fines) you can catch a bus back from Manly to The Spit Bridge. Great day out! Or half a day if you walk quickly.

Great Run!. Want to get a taste of Sydney before the arrival of the "first fleet"? Do the MST. This starts on the stairs on the spit bridge, and extends to the Manly wharf. You can extend this a bit by starting at the Taronga Zoo pier.This is a (mostly) contiguous nature reserve that extends the length of the walk. You'll see a lot of native plants and animals, and some Aboriginal artefacts (the kangaroo carving). This is about 10km from Spit to Manly, and add another 8km from Taronga. If you go to Manly beach, add another km.Make sure you have good shoes, and your camera, there's a lot of great views of the harbour. I've only walked this once. I've run it many dozens times, as training for trail runs. Take a water bottle, there aren't that many places to get water or use toilets. There's food near Spit and Manly, and at some of the beaches in between.

It's definitely worth it. Okay, it's ten kilometres but it's definitely worth the four hours walk. Excellent view. You'll be able to see little hidden beaches (and also take a swim if the water's not too cold).
Great coastal walk !. Manly is one of my favorite places! This walk takes about 4 hours. Great track on views of the harbour all the way. Great way to see Sydney!

A classic walk with beaches, coves and great views of the Harbour. This is a walk we take every year in Sydney. It offers great views of Sydney bay, the Heads, Manly and Sydney. It is an easy walk of 3-4 hours, longer if you swim in one of the coves and it can be done from either way. We usually take the ferry to Manly. As you exit the ferry, turn left and keep the water on your left: this is the only direction you will need. At the Spit you can take a frequent bus, or taxi, back to Sydney.

An absolute winner. I've been to Manly many times over the past 40 years, but had no idea that this wonderful walk existed until this month. Four of us did it on a warmish, Autumn Sunday (It would be a killer in full summer sun). It's a solid 12 km walk. There are quite a lot of steps in some places, but the views are well worth it. Standing directly in from of the Sydney Heads was a one of many great sights. Also very worthwhile were the indigenous rock engravings. These will be eroded sooner rather than later and are a real treasure that need to be visited asap. Other reviewers describe the walk as 'long' and suggest one has to be fairly fit. That's probably true of urban dwellers who don't walk regularly, but for those who walk often, this is a walk not a hike. However, while regular walking shoes are adequate there can be a bit of wet, even muddy dirt in places. Allow three hours plus in order to take in all the sites. Return to Manly by bus or, alternatively, take the bus to Spit Bridge and walk back.Tip: Take food and take plenty of water.Note: This is not a walk for people with limited mobility.

Steps, sea and lovely bush. Rated as a 4hr walk although we did it in 3hrs with stops. Great track on views of the harbour all the way. We were surprised how much bush there still was so close to the city. There are places to fill your water and use the toilet and the signage is pretty good. Last 2 kms of the walk, after forty baskets beach, is pretty urban but some of the houses are amazing. Great way to see the real Sydney, although it is the up-market part of the city.

One of the world's most beautiful walks. This walk is actually 2 walks in one. The section from Spit Bridge to the harbour beaches is mainly through bush on tracks. It is long and quite tiring and can be hot so bring hat etc plus water. This section takes you to the tops of the escarpment which gives the most outstanding views. These views are easily accessible by car and frankly that is OK unless you are a very keen walker because to get there on foot involves a fair bit of not so great walk through the scrub.For me the highlight of the walk is from the start of the beaches once the track meanders down on the northern section all the way to Manly. This part takes you through lots of small pretty secluded beaches (one is, or was, nudist) past boatsheds across a park and then a couple of kilometres of well made path only metres from the water to Manly. Outstandingly beautiful and it takes you past what is now Fairlight where Captain Phillip, the first Governor of Australia in 1788, met with the original inhabitants and was so impressed that he called the area Manly. This is now a tourist trap but still very worth the visit because of it's amazing location, beaches and other wonderful walks.

Long, moderately challenging, lovely walk. Long, moderately difficult walk with many steps and uneven surfaces. It's a full day if you stop to take photos or for rests and a meal as we did. My 18 year old son could do the full walk from Spit Bridge to Manly Beach in under 3 hours but I needed 4 and a half. Beautiful, diverse views made it worth it. Enjoyed the ferry ride back to Circular Quay with the Harbour lit up at night.

Fun in Manly. A fabulous walk and views of the coast. Once again have lunch in the beach café it is excellent highly recommended or stay a while and have dinner. The Ferries run until after Midnight..

A "Bush Walk" in the City. Another don't miss walk near Sydney. Lots and lots of steps and stairs - a lovely workout. Not as crowded as Bondi to Coogee but equally as stunning vistas. A little more nature. I would definitely make time for this one

must do whilst in Sydney. This walk in Spring is amazing, so many wildflowers many are edible if you know the onesamazing photo opportunitiesmany steps so if you have bad knees be preparedif you have a map you can do small sections of the walk, otherwise go all the way from Manly to the spit returning to Sydneycbd by bus.I like to take my time on this walk allow half a day

Spent my school holiday with the boys and girl in the split road resident , back in 1960's !. When I was young man I have live there for my school holiday . The house is owned by Doctor . He was working in the St. Vincent Hospital . His house is facing the entrance of the Sydney Harbour . I used to play with the children there . From his home , we can see the whole Sydney Harbour and watching the yacht racing. Really lovely scene ! They are living in the split road ! Below the split road there are yacht and boat parking there . I was very lucky to be there for my school holiday .

The Spit to Manly walk. Fantastic walk although you have to be fit enough to walk for a long length of time.what you will experience by taking this walk will remain with you for the rest of your life.

very much variation. longer than i thought, took me around 4 hours with photo-stops, but beautiful shots from the coast. from bushwalking to beach to waterfall to cliffs, you will see a lot of different things :)

Wonderful Walk so close to the Big City. 10 kilometres of pure physical pleasure - great views but so close to the city. Difficult in parts but nothing that anyone with average fitness can manage. Beautiful views over both manly and middle harbour. Take water with you and wear hiking shoes - sports shoes will not cut it and most certainly not R M Williams boots like we saw when last on the trail. Great way to spend a couple of hours before catching bus back, which ever way you do the walk

next best way to get to Manly. More great views, fewer people, more a suburban feel next to the beautiful harbour, with Manly the finish line if you head in the right direction. Second best only to the ferry.
Beautiful walk. Relaxing. Take a few hours out of your day, put on a pair of comfortable shoes, shorts and a t-shirt and enjoy the Sydney winter sunshine.
Great views. A 3 hour walk, catch bus 144 from Manly to the spit bridge. Beautiful views and clear water. Just make sure you take good shoes and some water
Amazing views, great walk. Bring water snacks, sun cream and good shoes. Get a bus to Spit bridge from wynyard then ferry back from manly.

Great early morning stroll. great way to start the day, a brisk walk with friend to Manly.
Parked the car at the Spit and caught a Taxi back after breakfast in Manly. Sometimes we forget how lucky we are to be living in Sydney
Beautiful coastal walk. The walk is quite long, so wear good shoes. It's a beautiful walk that shows stunning hidden beaches and great view points, definitely worth the effort. Allow minimum 3 hours.

A big day out. Catch the bus from the city to the Spit Bridge the walk over the bridge and turn right. The best time to do this walk is the Spring when the wildflowers on the coastal heath are out but anytime can be a treat. Catch the ferry back to the city from Manly.

2 hour walk. Very nice Sydney walk, great views and good healthy walk. You can get a 180 bus from the city for around 5 dollars and get the manly ferry back to circular quay for around 7 dollars it took around 2 hours for the walk and there's plenty of short cuts if you have google maps
Best walk in Sydney. Catch a bus to the spit and enjoy the walk! Take along your swimmers and a towel or even a little fishing rod. The views are brilliant and Manly is a great place to end up in.

This is a must do Sydney walk!. There are section of this walk where you could believe you were far away from any civilization, then around the next corner or over the next hill you see magnificent stretches of Sydney Harbour or the City or Manly ahead of you!
A walk in the bush by the harbour. Wonderful views of the entrance to Sydney Harbour. Easily accessible by public transport. So close to the city and yet so peaceful.

Great walk lovely views. We usually start at manly and ten turn round when we reach Spit Bridge a big walk sometimes take the dog but you have to go a different route to avoid beach areas. No where to get food or drink so take plenty of water and then stop at the many cafe's at manly a must for fit visitors.

A must do!. Had a great time exploring military structures. Great views of the Sydney skyline. Very diverse there was sections that had great ocean views and great city views as well as hanging swamp gardens and ponds.

The best of Sydney. This is a good walk that will take you past and through many of Sydney's terrains. It's a little bush, a little rocky, some beaches, some bridges but most of all it's just a scenic walk that has to be done whilst in Sydney. It takes a good three hours and is not entirely unchallenging, but oh so worth it. There's a few stairs in some parts, but most of it is relatively easy.

My second favorite walk in sydney. It's a great mix of suburban footpaths, beach and coastal tracks. I am always staggered how such an awesome walk can be so quiet. The walk from the spit bridge to the harbour bridge is better in my opinion.

Great walk, scenic views and a good option to escape the city life. This walk is a great opportunity to escape the busy city life. It's an easy but still adventurous walk along the coast with nice views and you can easily do in four hours. It's perfect for taking photos of the nature, Manly and the Sydney City skyline.

lovely !. We had a very nice walk along that lovely way.We used the free hop skip bus from Manly Stunning views ! But do not forget to bring water, hat and sunscreen.It took us half day because there are beautiful beaches, views, and lovely flora to see :)

The best coastal walk in Sydney. I've lived in Sydney and done a lot of walking, east side, north side and out west Sydney but this walk is by far the best! So quiet and peaceful with brilliant views over Sydney Harbour. Just make sure you time it well, it can often be wet after rain and a lot of the track is mud!

Bush walk by the Sea. One of the most beautiful bush seaside bushwalks. The walk is medium to hard and is 5 kilometres long. It will take approximately 1.5 hours. Along the way are beautiful beaches, stunning views out to to the Heads and Manly, and pretty native flora.Take drinking water and sun screen. Bus transport to Spit Bridge and from Manly back to the City or Chatswood is readily available.
Fun morning adventure. Great walk, the pathways have all been improved recently, lots of places for good breakfast at manly.

Don't miss this. A beautiful walk, stunning vistas. You can do the whole loop Spit to Manly or do it in segments to suit. Not difficult, but need good walking shoes. A few up hills and downhills but not steep. Loo stop at Tania park at midway point. Bushland and foreshore walk. The vies are well worth it. Loos and Cafes at Manly. Catch the bus back or take the ferry back to the city.

Beautiful harbour walk. beautiful Sydney Harbour walk along the shores and through the Aussie bush. If you like getting out and walking to experience the place you are visiting this is it. Camera, comfortable walking shoes, a water bottle, swimmers, money for coffee/lunch and you are set.

Favourite walk. What better way to enjoy the coastline. Catch a bus to the start at Spit Bridge then wonder through the beautiful coastline finishing at Manly Beach.Refresh at one of the many restaurants which you deserve after the walk then catch a ferry back to town.What better way to spend a beautiful Sydney day

Long but worth it.. Great wallk. You will see the heads and many watercraft and even get into some think scrub at points. Very safe in daytime but you need level of fitness and good shoes. Either way up or back is good.

Great way to see the harbour and keep fit at the same time.. Wear your trainers, pack a picnic and set off - ideal on any sunny day but if it;s hot make sure you allow for a dip at one of the little beaches on the way. Spectacular harbour views from every spot and if you're lucky the ice cream van will be at Tanya Park as you pass by. At the end of the walk stop off at the Wharf Bar in Manly to enjoy a long drink.

What a treasure. I heard about this from a random stranger I chatted to at a cafe out at North Head. She had bussed from Manly to The Spit Bridge and then walked back, but she said you could do it the other way, walk first and bus back. 10km she said, and a delight. Don't forget to take the time to enjoy the views along the way.So. I got some basic info from the a manly info centre near the Manly Wharf set off the next morning. Comfy sneakers or walking shoes, and hat, litre of water and a snack are well worth taking. It took me more than two and a half hours but I'm a fair walker. I did most little detours and one big one, and stopped to enjoy to view regularly. you don't have to be super fit but there are a lot of ups and ups and ups, and downs and downs, and lots of steps... It's not for the faint hearted.But I thoroughly enjoyed it. Once there ( at spit bridge) I crossed the bridge and had lunch at a ldelightfull little cafe called The Plank (or was it The Plonk) while I contemplated whether to bus back or walk.Unless you're super keen I'd do one way only. I did both and loved it, but I had no time pressure and I had all day. The walk back with less stops and detours was less than Two and a half hours but I was tired by the time I got back.Basically you just keep as close to the waters edge as you can. There are MSW signs (Manly Scenic Walk) and Google maps will help keep your bearings.I passed plenty of fellow walkers, none made me feel uncomfortable ... but it does get quite out of the way of everything so you may prefer to walk with a friend.There are quite a few toilet stops along the way if you look for them, but don't rely on shops or cafe's.The walk is a treat in either direction so choose what works for you.

Good walk, beaut views. Did this walk on a nice day, we were a little late starting ( due to making up our mind too late) which meant it was dark when we arrived at Manly, next time we would start earlier in day not lunch time

Keep fit and enjoy the view. Bring water, hat and sunscreen. Starts off on the wide pathways from the Manly End, nice coves and beaches and families out for a stroll. Terrain changes through headland scrub and dirt paths with some steeper sections and stairs. Some great views of the harbour and changing flora. Good exercise you need a moderate level of fitness to complete the walk especially if it is hot. Very worthwhile. Got a ferry to Manly and then the bus back to the City from the Spit.
Fantastic way to spend a morning or afternoon. Great walk, lots of variety and great views along the way, takes a good couple of hours but worth the walk.

Experience Sydney like a local. Today we spent a fantastic 2 hours walking. We did not want to walk the whole track so parked near Dobroyd Point. Lots of parking and it is FREE. Our 10 & 8 year skipped off down the path while my husband & I enjoyed looking at the wildflowers. The views are spectacular. We walked around the Manly 1 hour had a leasursly lunch after an ice cream the family was realy for the walk back. The path is well sign posted with information about the area.I have lived in Sydney for 30 years and never heard of 40 Basket Beach. Well worth a trip. Not suitable for prams or toddlers.
Great exercise and great views. This walk takes in beautiful natural views, and some of the nicest beaches around Sydney. Some parts are quite steep, but a great walk if you take the time you need.

Lovely but no signs!. Lovely walk with nice vistas! The map I got from the tourist information center, however, was extremely poor. I managed to find my way, but in some parts of the walk I had to go through some bushes and crawl over big rocks. This part could have done with some signs indicating where to go... Also, wear decent shoes (in stead of summer sandals or thongs)!
Great experience of the harbour and foreshore. This is a fairly easy walk with great views of the bush, some homes and the amazing harbour. Have fun.
Beautiful walk. Lots of National Park to walk through, beaches, bush and views. Well maintained path. Easy walk. Easy to start the walk by catching bus to the Spit from Carrington St.

Fabulous 10k walk with wonderful views and secret coves. I adored this walk and would rate it more highly than the Bondi Beach to Coogee walk which a lot of people do. Better still do both, they are totally different and a lovely way to get out of the city.For this walk, take the Manly ferry from Circular Quay to Manly, then stop off at the tourist information office as you disembark, the very helpful staff there will give you a map and details of how to pick up a bus back to the city when you finish. Grab some water, your camera, sun lotion if it's hot and a snack and head out.The views as you leave Manly and start to hug the coast are delightful, very quickly you are off the beaten track and wondering is you've wandered into paradise. The coves are tiny and for the most part you will be completely alone. The walk takes you along the coastline and through a number of nature reserves, the biggest of which is part of the Sydney Harbour National Park and includes Dobroyd Head. You climb quite steeply through native scrubland, but it's well worth the views from the top.The walk took me about 3 hours. I am a regular walker and am used to hills, although I did stop to take lots of pictures, so it may take others a little longer. I had a beautiful winters day but I can imagine in the summer it might be quite hot!One word of warning, there are a lot of steps, well maintained on the whole but they could be slippery in wet weather.When you finish, walk to the other side of Spit Bridge and pick up a 179 bus which will take you back to the city in about 30mins.

Spit to Manly Walk great experience. I have done this walk several times and love it. Winding through bush, lovely homes some amazing views. You do need to be fairly fit as some of the tracks are tricky, especially on the harbour at high tide. Get to Manly have some fish and chips with a glass of your favourite something, then walk back. Very, very enjoyable.

Best Walk in Sydney. You need to be reasonably fit and allow at least three hours for this walk. The views are amazing. When you get to Manly reward yourself with a nice meal and drink. Wear good quality walking shoes as there are some rough spots to conquer

A great city bush walk. I walked the Manly to The Spit track with a group of friends. Along the route are beach crossings and some spectacular views of Sydney Harbour and Middle Harbour. Walking on the well marked bush track is relatively easy and there are plenty of scenic stops along the way. Take some lunch and allow about 3 hours. We caught the ferry from Circular Quay to Manly, and the bus from The Spit back to the city. It's a great half-day activity in Sydney!

Just stunning. This was a highlight of Sydney for me. It's far nicer than the Bondi to Coogee walk (I'm not saying you shouldn't do that). Just breathtaking and it's not too strenuous. I started at spit so I couldn't finish in manly for some food and drinks. Pity the weather wasn't a bit better but it's that time of the year I suppose! Loved it!

Fabulous walk. This is for good walkers if you go all the way to the bridge bit it's worth it. Incredible views of the harbour. Take water with you and sun protection. Once at the bridge you can get a bus back to Manley.

Lovely walk great views. This is a beautiful walk hugging the harbour most of the way.Not recommended in wet weather as it would be very slippery and there are some steep stairs to climb.Stop at Clonny's café in Clontarf Park for a coffee before you start, great coffee, delicious muffins.We are retirees but found this walk pretty easy on the whole.If you are overweight or have any medical problems you may find parts a bit challenging but well worth it.Lots of nice views and native vegetation along the way.

Long and partially hilly hike with breathtaking views. We may have been a little naive when we embarked upon this expedition. As regular runners we thought 10k would be a breeze but we forgot to take into account the Australian climate (even in Winter) and the rugged terrain.Main tips? Sensible, comfy shoes and plenty of water and snacks.Although this is technically a coastal walk, you don't actually get to see all that much in the way of coast as most of the walk is along a tree-lined forest path. Where there are viewpoints however, the sea views are truly breathtaking - definitely worth taking a decent camera if you've got a comfortable camera bag.By the time we got to the 8k point we were stopping every 400m or so to have a little rest (there are plenty of benches) and we were very relieved when the harbour came into view at around the 9k mark. It was also at this point that we got to a beach where (at the right times of the year) you can see the native "Little Penguins" basking in the sun. They are currently mating and nesting though so we had to make do with the far less cute seagulls.When we finally reached Manly Harbour (about 4.5 hours after we set off from the Spit bridge) we were spoilt for choice in terms of places to rest our weary legs and fill our hungry bellies. We opted for Hugo's on the main wharf (reviewed separately) and we really enjoyed it! Once refreshed, we popped over to the beach (definitely worth a visit) and then hopped on the ferry back to Circular Quay.All in all, a very pleasant walk for those who like a good hike and are prepared to work for their views.
Easy to medium intensity walk. Follow Sydney coastline for most of the walk. Harbour views and fish and chips on the wharf at Manly with a ferry ride back to the city

Great way to see the harbour..and exercise. Not too much to be said other than it is a really good walk with some world beating views. Make sure you take some water along, there are some spots when you will be glad of it. When you get to Manly chill out and get the Ferry back to the city or the Bus back to The Spit.

a hidden gem. It is a long walk, but worth it. At one point there an open section and you find yourself kilometres above sea level and just an awesome blue ocean. Check out the aboriginal rock engravings as well. Finish in Manly with a cold one.

Day out with exercise and great views. Nice walk have to be fairly fit able to manage stairs and walking up and down hills. Fantastic views of Sydney. Well worth the effort. Train to Wynyard, bus to Spit Bridge. Do the walk, lunch at Manly and catch the ferry back to Circular Quay. Take in the Opera House and catch the train home. Great day.
Manly to Spit. Quite a strenuous walk but worth it through coastal forest with great views of the Harbour. Take water and use good shoes.

Great Walk Great Views. Great walk to see the inner harbour of Sydney, good workout also and views around every corner fairly easy impact, no wheelchair or stroller access, good walking joggers a must.

long easy walk. A very scenic walk with some steep spots but generally not hard work The views from most of the walk are sensational with the top of the walk looking straight past North Head to the ocean. Whilst below hidden amongst the rocks are the depression started artist shacks that was the beginning of much of the famous Australian artists. Finish up at the Manly Wharf Hotel or 4 Pines for a well earned thirst quencher.

Spit to Manly or Manly to Spit. This is a great walk, not just for the scenery but it is a lot less expensive than a workout at the Gym. However you can just do part of the walk or you can do what I do and walk to Manly, have lunch then walk back, you will be tired at the end of the day but you will love the beauty along the way whilst receiving a great workout. I have seen people do it in thongs or sandals, however there are lots of uneven steps and I think you should have good walking shoes.Take water as there is no where to get it on the walk and use a light day pack with some snacks and water. About half way there is a great coffee shop and nearby there are public toilets. I can't say how long it will take as everyone walks at a different pace and how often you stop to take in the views, but give it a go, you won't regret it

An unmissable 10k coastal walk for the reasonably fit.. Starting at Spit Bridge and following the track and signs all the way to Manly is great. The views are spectacular and you find all sorts of bays and marinas that you would hardly know existed if you just travelled by car.If you start at about 10am and take 2 hours for the walk, you can get lunch in Manly and then get a taxi back to Spit bridge.

One of the most varied scenic walks!. We visit Bondi Beach twice a year to spend time with family. This last visit we took this walk for the first time. Our 'go to' walk is Bondi to Coggee. This was a real treat. Fewer people, more challenging, and fabulous scenery and vistas. Seeing the variety of neighborhoods up close was an added bonus. Can't recommend this walk enough. We took the bus from downtown to the far side of the Bridge and walked down the stairs. We took the ferry back from Manly. A must do for anyone who wants to get away from the typical tourist attractions!
Amazing Views. Views along the walk are amazing. Dont do this walk in the heat. There are no water fountains and shelter along this walk. Watch out for water dragons too!

Enjoyable day out. train to Wynyard station, bus to South side of Spit Bridge. Start the walk on North side of bridge. If you're luck enough you'll see the bridge open to allow a yaght through, like I did. Medium fitness required, in the wet months, definitely walking shoes, can be quite wet in parts, at time you need to wade through if you walk the beach. So many different aspects and views of the landscape, breathtaking in places. Reward at the end, take the walking shoes off, wade in the ocean, partake in a Belgium Beer at Manley Wharf.

Medium level walk. Great walk on a fine day. Take Bus 279 from Wynyard station. Ring the bell as you are going over Spit Bridge. You get off the bus about 200m past Spit bridge, walk back towards bridge and take left turn into Avona ...walk down maybe 250m, track starts off to the left. If you are able to do a 10km walk on flat ground in say 2 hours, you will do this one to the main drag in Manly in an easy 3 hours. That allows for a few photo stops and time for a quick snack from your backpack. Don't forget the camera.

What a great walk with friends on a nice day.. Enjoy Sydney harbour views, get exercise and fresh air and even discover aboriginal drawings on a rock. And when you arrive at Manly a great choice of places to have lunch. This is one of many Sydney walks and a particularly enjoyable one.

great walk. great views - steep in parts. Don't bring a car as parking in Manly is difficult to find and expensive. Watch out for tides, we had to wade through water on the the way back but to be fair, this was one of the high points. Also lots of good short walks from Manly
Absolutely fabulous. Gorgeous views and great work out thrown In. Will do it again. Harmonises vistas with the incredible amount of national park a stone's throw from the city.

I was thinking better!. I was there with a friend. First time for both.Tried to go fast because was little bit late, closer to the sunset. We spend 3 hours to arrive in Manly. I was thinking better because I was expectating more views..Instead there is only 1-2 . Yes, that are spectacular. Other thing to watch is vegetation. Ok, done!

Loved it. A great way to spend a beautiful sunny day in Sydey. The walk took us about 3 hours with lots of stops along the way to admire the views and take photographs. It is reasonably easy terrain but I would recommend good walking shoes and a water bottle. Have lunch at one of the cafes along the beachfront in Manly at the end of the walk.

Harbour walk. Fantastic scenery along the way. It is about 10 km between the Spit and Manly and it is well sign posted. I have run and walked it on a few occasions and never tire of its wonder. Beautiful little bays, beaches, rocky outcrops and some ancient Aboriginal rock carvings in the sandstone are just some of the features you will notice. Most of the people along the way are enjoying the same great walk. Catch the bus (190? and a few others that head north), disembark at The Spit, walk to Manly, lunchan/or swim and ferry back to Sydney. A nice day in Sydney will be had by all!

Another view of Sydney Harbour & Manly. The Spit to Manly walk commences at the northern (Seaforth) side of the Spit Bridge and follows the harbour front to Manly, a northern harbour and ocean surf beach, with many bars and restaurants. The walk provides access to Clontarf (Sandy) and Washaway Beaches and some beautiful scenery, including littoral vegetation, harbour-front sandstone cliffs and historic squatters cottages, which are open on weekends for viewing.A short part of the walk into Manly is along the road before re-joining the esplanade and ending at Manly ferry wharf, where are plenty of places to eat and drink. A short walk through the Manly Mall brings you to the Manly ocean surf beach and if you're really keen you can continue south to Shelley Beach, which is quite sheltered and has some interesting diving.

Escape the city and take in some commanding harbour views. At just under 10km, the walk should take around 2-3 hours depending on your fitness and of course how many times you stop to take pictures!The first km is fairly uneventful, skirting Fisher Bay with the sound of traffic still ringing in your ears. Clontarf Reserve is a super place for a picnic, with wide beaches, a netted swimming area and a great park and play area for kids. The next 5km take you round the edge of Dobroyd Head, giving you great views back to Balmoral and out towards the Tasman Sea. The path until Forty Baskets Beach is hard-packed dirt single-track, with plenty of steps - not suitable for rolling transport!Continuing from Forty Baskets Beach, the path is metalled all the way into Manly. If travelling with wheels, be sure to take Condamine Street up to Lauderdale Avenue, bypassing North Harbour Reserve, else continue up the steps and onto the spectacular harbour-side path.Toilets are located at Clontarf Reserve, North Harbour Reserve, Fairlight Beach and of course Manly, with water taps at each.

Spit Bridge to Many Coastal Walk. The Spit Bridge to Many Coastal Walk is a 10km walk from the Northern end of Spit Bridge to Manly. It is a moderate walk and takes you through Sydney Harbour National Park as well as a few suburban streets... To get to the start, your best bet is to either a) Drive to the Spit Bridge and walk to Manly, then catch a bus back to Spit Bridge. OR b) Bus to Spit Bridge and then either bus back to your destination and if your destination is in the city, a ferry back to Circular Quay is another option. It is advisable to take plenty of water and supplies with you as there are not that many facilities along the way and it can get quite hot during summer. Keep it a little on the light side though as it is a 10 km walk.Take your swimmers as there are opportunities to swim during summer.You will get plenty of chances for fabulous city and Manly pictures along the way and additionally there are aboriginal rock art works. Not really recommended for small children or prams as parts of the track can get a little rough.Ending up at Manly, there are plenty of eating opportunities as well as great beach.Highly recommended nature walk very close to the city and highlights the hidden beauty spot that are hidden all around Sydney.Note: As you travel though a National Park, Dogs and other domestic animals are not permitted.

Incredible experience, would definitely recommend. Doing the Spit Bridge to Manly walk was a phenomenal experience. At Spit Bridge, I was lucky enough to be able to witness the bridge rising in order to let boats pass through underneath, which was a real treat as I had never seen anything like that before. The walk itself was great- it was very tranquil, quiet and peaceful throughout. There were some tricky bits here and there where the path narrowed to the point where it couldn't have been more than a metre across, plus there sometimes would be trees and bushes obstructing the path every now and then which needed to be ducked under. Not exactly very well-maintained, but definitely not a reason to avoid doing the walk altogether and the good far outweigh the bad.It took about 4 to complete, and by the end I was pretty drained, so make sure that you're well-prepared by wearing comfortable shoes, applying sunscreen, and bringing lots of water. Overall, would wholeheartedly recommend to anyone willing to do a bit of walking.

So close to the city, but a completely different world. My Finnish friend and I took the ferry from Circular Quay to Manly and were very lucky with the weather. After a couple of minutes we already saw some really nice, isolated beaches and had to push ourselves to not stop every 5 minutes. After about 2 hours, we found a completely isolated beach which we could only access by climbing over spiky rocks and getting all wet, but we had a beautiful beach full of shells to ourselves and probably spent 2 or 3 hours there. The entire walk is beautiful, on one hand the ocean is always on your left side, but on the other hand you feel like you're in the middle of a jungle with all kinds of small bridges and plants. I unfortunately forgot my sunscreen and after a sunny day in the Australian summer, I was very sunburnt, so don't forget your sunscreen! We took the bus back to the city from The Spit. If you only have limited time in Sydney and have to decide between this walk and the Bondi - Coogee Walk, definitely go with this one. Even though it's longer and more exhausting, it's absolutely worth it!

Leave the city behind and yet so accessible. This really is a great walk and perfect to take visiting friends on. Even though it is a long walk(over 3 hrs) it is an easy walk. We were accompanied by teenagers and pre teens and they completed it without complaining. It helps to have an ice cream break at the Clontarf kiosk. The walk goes through beach and bush and there are a couple of detours you can take. On a beautiful day this is the ideal thing to do in Sydney. It's free and easy. There is plenty of parking at the spit and buses back from Manly if you don't want to walk back.

Spit Bridge to Manly walk.. Our son and his wife took us on this walk, which takes about 3 1/2 hrs. It meanders through rain forests with man made pathways, has two little waterfalls, hidden coves and beaches, sailing marinas, and lots of other hidden gems. There are two toilet blocks en route, and a cafe mid way, for those needing a break or two! Take good walking shoes, not flip flops and a camera for those stunning view So!
Great walk. Great walk around Sydney's beautiful harbour. Great views and nice little beaches. Bring your picnic with you and you will have a great day out.Enjoy!!!

Excellent urban hike.. This nice, fairly long hike covers several different terrain types and offers excellent views of different parts of Sydney. Look for the cool, huge lizards along the way.See views of the city from a distance, walk through some interesting neighborhoods and end at Manly Beach for lunch, drinks and a pleasant ferry ride back to Circular Quay and see the Opera House from the water.Not exactly strenuous but may be somewhat challenging for some who aren't accustomed to longer hikes.

Excellent Walk Within City Limits. Very nice walk with easy transport options from Sydney CBD. Strongly recommend this as a great half day out of the city centre. Don't forget to include an ice cream and a swim at Manly Beach.

Great walk around the harbour. Delightful walk beside the harbour with not too many ups and downs. We did this as a training walk for a bigger hike and stopped at Manly for lunch before returning to make a great round trip!

Great walk with great views. I have trekked along the route from Manly ferry wharf to the Spit Bridge many times. It is a walk of about 10km. Parts of it are along flat paved pathways, but most of it is bush track which includes rough patches with rock stairs. At times you will be using short sections of roadway.You need to be reasonably fit with good knees and hips due to the many ups and downs encountered. You will be rewarded however with great views over Manly and the Heads, as well as native flora and even Aboriginal rock carvings. Towards the end is a park where you can grab lunch or a coffee, or even have a swim. I generally do the walk in just under two hours, but that is at a reasonably fast pace.Pros- it's FREE- you get to see great views. Take a camera.- it's reasonably well signposted.- there is a coffee shop with lunch available towards the end- at the Spit are also coffee shops and places for lunch.- there are a few water bubblers along the way but mainly in the first section within small park areas that you walk through. I suggest you carry some water.Cons- you need a reasonable degree of fitness for some sections involving steps.- the track could be sloppy in wet weather- you could accidentally get side-tracked in some places if you don't find the direction signs.- only the first small part of the way in wheelchair accessible.Suggestions- take a camera- take some water- wear good flat shoes with traction- wear sunscreen and a hat- look out for the path direction signs and check the maps which are placed at various spots along the route.To get there, catch the Manly ferry to Manly wharf, leave the wharf and turn left towards the aquarium.At the Spit, walk across the bridge, cross to the western side of the road and catch the bus back to Manly (route 143 or 144). The stop is about 100m from the southern end of the bridge, directly across the road from Zest Waterfront Venues.Enjoy beautiful Sydney.

Amazing harbour-side walk in the middle of the city. This is a fantastic walk from Spit to Manly. I always love starting at the Spit Bridge end, fuelling up with the delicious fish'n'chips at Clonny's. The walk has spectacular views of the harbour, as well as moments of pure bushland - making it seem hard to believe that you are walking just minutes away from some of the most expensive real estate in the country. A pretty easy walk, but some parts can get quite muddy after some rain. Reward yourselves with something delicious in Manly - I usually indulge in a gelato at the wharf ;-)

Good walk, some really scenic points.. Firstly I'd say this was my second favourite after Bondi to Coogee beach. We always like walking by the coast and this was no exception, although there is more walking amongst trees between the view points than on the other. Glad we did it. If taking the bus to Spit bridge to start, best way, then make sure you get off the bus before crossing the bridge as crossing the road with heavy traffic afterwards is difficult.
Spit bridge walk.. Takes you along lovely scenic route. Do however give yourself 3/4 hours to complete walk. Dont forget your camera, the cliff top views are amazing.
Beautiful way to see Sydney Harbour. Need to be reasonably fit as its a serious hike, bring a water bottle and a good camera, its hard to believe that its free

Great views of Sydney and hidden small beaches. That walk is pretty long but awesome. You will need to allow yourself 4/5hours to do it. Worth to take a picnic along and just have a break at one of the hidden beaches you would see on your way.

Magnificent walk along beaches, see amazing houses, views of the water, through bush. A fantastic walk to do whether your a tourist or local.You climb through bush, walk along the beach and come across amazing houses set in amongst the trees. People walk, or even run the route.You can stop and take a dip in the sea at most points and you are away from the crowds.You see the headland at many points and are gobsmacked at the beauty, Its takes over 2hrs to do the walk at a reasonable pace, when you are in manly near the jetty you feel absolutely ready for a glorious ice-cream or a dip in the sea.Everybody should do it at least once, Done solo or as a group, young or old its manageable for all.Just do it !
Nice day. Take a day for this walk, you'll find little beach where you'll want to have a break and you should take time to swim in this wonderful scenery !

Do this!!. I fell in love with Sydney on this hike. Amazing way to see a different side of the city, hiking along a well-marked trail that snakes along seaside cliffs, charming coves and cute neighborhoods. Bring your camera! Some of the views are jaw-dropping. Bring water too! It's a long'ish (6+ mile) hike and it can get hot! Tip: If you are staying in DT Sydney, have a cab drop you off near the Spit Bridge, then hike to Manly, reward yourself with a beachside lunch and drink, then catch the "government ferry" back to downtown Sydney. The best $7 I have ever spent (ferry ticket).

Must do walk/run. The views! This is my regular running track and I live along it. Some of the most beautiful hidden harbour beaches are along this track, so pack some cozzies if you want to swim. Clontarf is stunning, as is Castle Rock Beach & Forty Baskets. You get to see a lot of water dragons -a native lizard -it won't hurt you. There are taps to drink from and toilets at Clontarf, Forty Baskets, Middle Harbour & all along the Fairlight harbour walk. There are cafes along the route. From the Spit to Manly -it's under 10kms. Joggers are perfect foot wear.

Fresh Sunday Morning Walk. We went early in the morning to avoid as much of the hot sun. You can take it as fast as slow as you want. There are many idyllic locations for a picture, a rest or a swim. We waiting until we were a bit closer to manly and swam at Fairlight rock pool. It was divine after the hot hike on a lovely summer morning.Followed by some fish and chips in Manly Wharf Hotel and then caught the bus back to our car at spit bridge.

Great Walk. I loved seeing all the different types of coast. You are able to see many environment and plants in a relatively small area. Take lots of water as it is a long walk. Easy to grab a bit or have a restroom break about every km or so. It will end at Manly Beach just a short walk from the ferry docks with regular ferries to Sydney.

Great way to see a different side of beautiful Sydney. This walk is a fantastic way to see some beautiful bushland and coastal scenery with spectacular views of Sydney Harbour, Middle Harbour, the Heads, secluded harbour beaches, Aboriginal rock carvings, native flowers and Manly Cove. And it's free!

Beautiful. What a beautiful walk! You feel like you're a million miles from the city, and stopping off at secluded beaches along the way for a dip makes you feel like you're a million miles from anywhere. It took us way longer than it should have as I stopped to look at every lizard and bird I could see, but that just made it all the better. Bumping into a nesting family of Tawny Frogmouths really made this a walk I'll never forget.
Wow ,absolutely beautiful. Great walk ,a good 2 - 3 hours ....but stunning ,we enjoyed immensely ,,,,Then catch bus back to Manly ,,,for ferry ,Wonderful day out

Great walk with spectacular views. I walked today the trail from Manly to Spit bridge you will see some great views along the trail and if your lucky dome huge dragon lizards. The trail is for the most part easy to walk with some rocky hills up and down on some of the parts. Make sure you bring enough water and your swimsuit to use the pools or beaches along the trail.

It's LONG!!!!. Much longer than 9 km! Bring water, snacks, and good sturdy hiking shoes. The walk is up and down, up and down, up and down many many steps. It took us 5 & 1/2 hours!!! The guide book says 9 km and 3 - 4 hours. We ran out of water, didn't have any food, and wore teva sandals. Be prepared! We also went during the hottest part of the day! Having said all that, I would do it again in a heartbeat! The rewards are jewels! Views, wildlife, and aboriginal carvings in rock. We stumbled into the Manly pier and stopped at an outdoor pub where we gulped wine and devoured delicious pizza at the end.

Pleasant harbourside walk, not too challenging. Caught the 180 bus from the city to Spit Bridge to start the walk so we could finish at Manly, have a bite to eat/cup of coffee and then travel back to the city via the Manly Ferry. Suggest you hop off at the stop just before the Spit Bridge as there are clean toilets in the park, and you can then walk over the Spit Bridge before commencing the Walk. The walk took us 3.5 hrs, which included a stop for lunch and also a swim at the beautiful quiet little Reef Beach. The walk is not too challenging and is very scenic with beautiful views of the Harbour. The Aboriginal Rock Carvings at the Grotto are also very interesting. Take your swimmers as there are a number of quiet beaches along the way. At some places you may get your feet wet or have to take a short diversion if it is high tide. We saw some lovely wildflowers, a few bush turkeys and a number of water dragons. A great walk, definitely recommend it.

Beautiful, serene. Parked at the Spit and had to wait for the bridge to open and close, a good way to start our walk. Not too challenging, scenic, had to walk thru the water because of high tide, lovely views of the different bays, enjoyed lunch on the Corso, a great walk, definitely recommend it to both Sydneysiders and visitors alike.
WALK. Relaxed and can take your time. There is so much to do in Manly at the end of this walk you will have a smile on your face.

My home turf.
