My house is right on the tip of Manly's North Harbour, so this wonderful walk is right outside my front door.I normally do the walk from the Manly end.You will have spectacular views of Sydney Harbour and out through North and South Heads.Depending on the season you will see an abundance of Original Australian flora and bird life, You often see various types of Australian lizards and occasionally a snake. Just keep out of the snakes way and it will not bother you.I do the walk for exercise so it takes me about an hour. A more lcomfortable pace would be two hours.

Don't forget your walking boots.. It's a great medium sized walk. Can be a bit iffy in places, but it is well worth your while, as are all the walks in Sydney. Lets face it, if you can see water it has got to be good.
waterside walk. easy walk and beautiful scenery buses at both ends and plenty of food available also at ends . take your swimmers for a dip at Clontarf., showers and change room available.

Spit to Manly walk. This is a great walk for committed walkers with fabulous views around Sydney Harbour. Although well constructed and clearly signposted some of the walk can be a little bit rough. Also, there are very few opportunities to get off the walk - once you are on it you need to keep going. Not recommended for the casual walker. Allow at least 3 hours.

The Spit to Manly. This has to be one of the most scenic walks in the world, it takes a good three hours, but you can stop and have a swim at several places along the way if you get too hot . Highly recommended !

Long bush walk. Allow several hours to complete this walk but this illustrates the beauty of Sydney as bush and nature exists in all areas of the city . The walk follow the coastline from the Spit Bridge to Manly where you can stop and enjoy many restaurants , cafes and a beach swim at the end of your walk
Classic Walk. It is an OK walk but has some really boring bits towards the end - walking on urban streets that are uninspiring

Ideal any time. This 3 hour walk is a relatively unchallenging but highly scenic stroll around the harbour foreshore to beautiful Manly. In summer you can stop at a number of beaches to swim along the way, and any time of the year it is usually perfect to paddle or enjoy the stunning views of craft and bayside parks natural flora.

Yes, yes, yes...Take this walk. This is a way cool coastal walk. It's worth the trip over from Sydney just for the hike. This isn't a flip-flop hike-walk. This isn't a little kiddie or stroller walk. Take real walking shoes. Not a strenuous walk, just kinda long, kinda hot with some killer views as well as ups and downs.Ferry over from Sydney and Take a cab (~$20) from ferry to the bridge spit. Easy trail and well maintained. Up hills and down hills. Takes 2 plus hours. I liked this walk better than Bondi to Coogee. Much more varied walk and terrain. I say do both! And then eat at a beach cafe in Manly, swim in the ocean and enjoy.

Feel a million miles from the city with spectacular views. Look at the city and beautiful bays and inlets as you walk through scrub and bush land. At points you will feel you are miles away from the city and then you will be viewing the bridge and magnificent beaches through the trees. Take a drink and your swimming costumes. It can get hot and you can cool off swimming as you go. Relax at Manly when you arrive at one of the many bars or restaurants. Or carry a snack to eat as you walk. Really beautiful. Gets hot so take a hat in summer.

A taste of the Australian bushland in a walk. This walk is quintessentially Australian. Experience the flora and fauna with beautiful Sydney harbour by your side. And when you have finished you can get a beer and food!

Good alternative to Bondi-Coggee. A 10K walk through woodland and sea-front, with at least one good beach swim about half way. And great views of the Gap between North and South heads. Allow 4 hours including a short swim. Recommend starting at Spit Bridge so you can end in Manley, have a beer and get the ferry back to Circular Quay. You can catch the bus outside the QVB, every 15 mins or so, 30-35 min journey. Get off at the Spit Bridge stop, virtually on the bridge, cross the bridge and turn right. We made the mistake of going on one further stop, ending up in the suburbs and doubling back. The first short stage is along a suburban fore-shore but the walk gets quieter with great sea views. Loos available along the way.

Loved it!. Some really nice views, nature, beaches and places to see all along the walk. Best to really take your time and appreciate everything. Most of the walk is pretty well marked out which is good.

Great walk. Completed this walk on a hot day and in flipflops (which was stupid, but we'd started so we finished) - best wear trainers or sturdy shoes. It took the whole morning and was relatively strenuous but views along the way make the effort more than worthwhile.

One of my favourite walks in Sydney.. I love this walk, it meanders from Manly and then five minutes walk from Manly you feel like you're miles away from Sydney and all the people (although you're not because half of Sydney is doing the walk with you!). Take food, drink and walking shoes, and even bathers. There is a great place to go swimming on the way. Also, toilet facilities along the way too. There is car parking available at the end of the walk. A lovely place to share with friends or as a couple (next time I'm going with someone). A most enjoyable walk.
make sure your fit to do this one. along the walk it has marvellous views. Take food and plenty of water as its a long walk but much enjoyable

Great Walk with Stunning Views!. This is a moderate walk of about 7kms. If you start from the Spit Bridge the first fews kms are a little steep, but once you are at the top the view if so worth it! There are lots of nice coffee places and eateries at the Manly end! Try having a bite and then turning around to head back to the Spit Bridge! A great walk!

Trail run to Manly. I actually started in downtown Sydney and went for a long run across the Harbour Bridge and along the coast, which included the Spit Bridge to Manly section. I really enjoyed the hilly stretch from Spit Bridge to Manly. There were great views of the coast, included Sydney in the distance. You also get a nice view of Manly from up on the hill.I would highly recommend this ~10km walk / run.

Well worth the effort. The route is quite tricky in parts, there are a fair number of steps to climb, the heat can be very challenging , but with plenty of water and regular sitting in the shade we managed, the scenery is wonderful, take swim wear to cool off along the way

One of the best. I have done this walk many times with friends and family. An easy relaxing walk suitable if you have young ones or not so fit older ones!Not very challenging but rewards come elsewhere. Couple of beautiful beaches / stopping points along the way where you can take a dip on a hot day. Stunning views and many photo opportunities. Aboriginal carvings. Then when you get to Manly you can rewards yourselves with a beautiful meal as there is plenty to choose from. Once with friends our reward was the beer cafe on the wharf - but not with family as this place does not allow children inside. Then to top the day off there is the ferry ride back to circular Quay.

Take your camera. Not good if you go just after a few days of ran as the track can get muddy but just make sure you wear appropriate shoes.I live locally and use this track as a running trek early morning a few times throughout the year.Take a camera and get up early to see the sun come up and then finish off in Manly for breakfast.It's FREE and a little gem if you want harbour views
One of the most rewarding walks you will do in Sydney. An excellent slightly challenging walk with amazing coastal scenery and plenty of beaches for a drip along the way. Allow 3 hours.

Manly to the Spit. I actually walked in the opposite direction from Manly to the Spit but obviously the views and the ambience are just the same. Stunning views all the way! Walk is well shaded.If you go at low tide you can walk along the harbour between Reef Beach and 40 Baskets and this cuts the time down considerably. This deviation is well signposted.I would allow about 4 hours but if you're hungry to get to the restaurants in Manly I'm sure you can do it in less. Well worth the effort.

Very pleasant walk. This has to be one of the best spots in Sydney. If you are interested in scenic bush walks then this is a great example. Some mild up and downs in parts but not difficult. The views that are on offer and the tranquility provided in many areas along the track let you think you are a lot further from civilisation than reality. The convenience of the bus service at each end is perfect. Take your time and stop to enjoy. This is an excellent facility that allows any of us to appreciate the foreshore area of a picturesque harbour.

Great walk with spectacular views.. Start of walk a little hard to find after getting off the bus at The Spit also had to cross very busy 4 lane highway which we didn't expect. Beautiful beaches and coves passed at start of the walk then through quite good bush tracks. Great views the higher we got and lots of shade in the bush. Take plenty of water and your bathers as lots of opportunities to swim early on. Long walk but worth it.

Moderate walk. This is a moderate walk with some steps, paid parking is available at the Spit Bridge area and you can get a bus back fro Manly or walk back. Signage is not as great as it could be and there are some parts which go up small streets. Plan it out so you keep on the walk.Dobroyd Point is a great place to see the Harbour at its best, there are places to swim the closer you get to Manly. I would not call this an easy walk but its not too hard either.

Beaut Walk. We caught the 144 bus from Manly Wharf to the Spit. There's a track leading down from Avona Cres to the start of the walk, so no need to tangle with the traffic on Spit Rd.The track is in good condition mainly passing through bush above the shoreline and in places along the waterline. There's beautiful views of Middle Harbour in the stretch up to Grotto Point. After that the track passes round Dobroyd Head with big views across the Heads and Sydney Harbour. There's plenty of opportunity to stop for a swim at small beaches along the way at Clontarf, Castle Rock, Reef, Forty Baskets and Fairlight beaches. This is a great way to get a feel for the wild parts of Sydney Harbour.

One Of The Best In Sydney Harbour. It is a ten km walk and there are steps up and down but the scenery is worth the effort. The scenery changes from the start from dry to sub-tropical. You do see a range of views of the harbour and something not to be missed.
Excellent . This hike is not very difficult and takes 3-4 hrs. Lots of excellent views along the way. A very peaceful way to pass half a day.
Great trek!. My friend and I did this walk and enjoyed every minute of it, despite the rain! It's not too difficult of a trek, and the views are lovely!

Taronga Zoo to Manly Pacific Hotel - wonderful days walk. the walk I did was a few years ago from Taronga Park Zoo and Surius Cove to The Manly Pacific Hotel via the Quarantine Station. It should be a must on everyones TO DO LIST. Allow a day to enjoy all the scenery and enjoy an ice cream and rest at The Spit. Sit and watch the array of boats and yachts coming and going all day. And finish the day at Manly Pacific and your favourite drink. Mine was a well deserved Shandy

Really good walk. Absolutely loved this walk as you get to quite a few hidden gems away from the crowds. We went for a swim in one of the secluded beaches along the walk.
The only downside is that getting on the bus from the spit bridge back to the city or the upper north shore is a bit of an hassle.
worth it. Easy walking either way. Good views of coast and lots of hidden beaches for swims. Good cafe at Spit Bridge end and bus 180 back to city from there if start at Manly.

A good hike with splendid view of the harbour and city. This is the hike I usually did with visitors who like a good hike. Starting on the Spit Bridge (take the bus there from Manly Wharf) and leads along the shore, harbour beaches, cliffs, bush... towards Manly Wharf. Make sure you wear good sturdy shoes and are reasonably fit because there are plenty of stairs and the walk talks a good few hours. You will be satisfied with great views and scenery!!!

Spectacular scenery. We started the 10 km walk from the Northern side of The Spit bridge. It's fairly well signposted. The walk involves lots of steps, ( some steep) gravel paths and some boardwalks. It offers spectacular views of the city, harbour and Manly. The wild flowers were beautiful, especially , the flannel flowers , bottle brushes and grevilleas. We also saw lots of bearded dragons. Take plenty of water and snacks as there are none until you get to Manly. Wear a hat and sunscreen and joggers. It took us 3 hrs 20 mts but take time to enjoy this fabulous walk.

Spit Bridge to Manly Walk. This walk is so popular it is in danger of being "over-loved". It is probably a good idea to choose a time about mid-morning, after the exercise fiends have gone home. It takes a leisurely five hours and there are beautiful views all along the way. If you are specially lucky around Christmas you might see some red and gold Christmas Bells. Either catch a bus to the Spit Bridge - the walk starts from the northern side. Once you have reached Manly there is either the harbour pool or a short walk to the surf for a refreshing swim. If you happen to be there during the winter, the views are still there but perhaps you might prefer to visit the Manly Art Gallery, which you pass at the western end of the harbour pool.

Spectacular walk. We started at Spit Bridge after getting the bus from CBD. We were lucky to be with my son who lives here who knew which bus stop to get off at as it was not obvious. Then started the 10k walk of varying terrains. At some points the steps were quite taxing but for 50 plusers managed ok with a stop halfway at one of the beautiful beaches. The walk is a mixture of stone paths, steps & wooden boardwalks. We spotted plenty of lizard varieties basking along the path. Take water & snacks but remember no bins along this walk I assume because of wildlife so please don't spoil this wonderful environment and take litter home with you. When you get near to Manly the walk takes you through a residential area & park but this is interesting to see the houses in this prestigious location. The Bavarian Bar at Manly Wharf was certainly a welcome sight and beers and hotdogs went down as a well earned reward. Loved this walk. Would definitely recommend it.

Great diversity of environment on the walk, great views. My wife and I did the walk in summer. We are not youngsters! We drove to the spit bridge and parked on the sydney side of the bridge and then did the walk and caught the bus back from Manly to the spit. The walk took about 3 hours. was easy for most of it and hard for some parts. taking it easy is the key to doing it. Dont rush. take water and snacks. well marked path. huge diversity of native plants on the way. great views of sydney harbour and manly. We have done many of the walks around sydney harbour and this is one of the most challenging so take your time. the harder bits are in the first 1/3 of the walk from the spit. You really enjoy food and drinks at one of the many Manly restaurants or cafes when you get there!! If the temperature was much more than low 30s I would not do it on that day. Morning would be best and low tide is better than high tide. We saw quite a few eastern australian water dragons on the walk which are always great to see. Stopping at the Arabanoo Lookout is worth it later in the walk. When you read that cafes are on the way (in some websites they mean at the end of the walk as there are none for 90% of the walk.

Great scenery. Have done this walk both ways now it never gets boring. Although it can get very hot there are places were you are in dappled shade. Take water, snacks, camera and wear comfortable covered in footwear. Some great scenery. If low tide there are spots where you can walk along the beach otherwise follow the track. Saw some very large water dragons along the way on the path.

Stunning scenery. We ventured along this walk in the Manly to Spit Bridge direction. The walk takes you through some beautiful suburban areas of Manly, with spectacular, ever changing views of the coastline and harbour. The path is gently undulating to begin with, but there are some short steep climbs along the route. The path is well managed, but is some places, steps are in need of repair and you need to watch your footing. This is evidently about to be rectified as concrete blocks had already been delivered to areas of bad wear.We took the walk on a warm (31C) afternoon. There was plenty of shade, but it is essential to carry water as we did not see anywhere on route where we could have obtained any.On the day we walked, the tide was relatively low and we were able to enjoy long stretches of the walk on the foreshore. In one place this involved a scrabble over some rocks. We do not know whether we missed the path markings, or if this was the intended route. However, it was great fun and added some extra interest to our walk. There is an alternative higher path if the tide is in.The path is marked as being about 8km. It felt longer, and took us about 3 hours to complete, taking our time and enjoying the scenery, but ceratinly was not unpleasant and we would recommend

Great Walk, Great Views, Bring LightMeal+Snacks+Water, Weather Dependent. My wife and I had an excellent time doing this walk...I wouldn't plan on doing anything else unless you start early...As the title says, but a few tips below...1. Check the weather before you walk. It's better at low tide, but there are good signs for tracks catering to High tide conditions. 2. Bring snacks and a Camera/iPhone, it's about 3 hours one way. We brought an Apple, Sandwich, A pack of muesli bars, and 1L water each...3. Stop and enjoy the Views4. Start at the Spit, there's a walk way under the bridge, then relax at Manly Beach. Websites that I found helpful other than TripAdvisor of course!http://members.ozemail.com.au/~russo/oceanbeach/spit.htmlhttp://short-walks.com.au/new-south-wales/sydney/spit-bridge-to-manly-walk/5. There are a couple of Bathroom stops.6. I'd recommend buying an opal card if you taking public transport.

Stunning views and a great walk. Take the bus to the Spit Bridge from the city and them walk all the way to Manly. Then catch the Ferry back to Circular Quay. The walk is packed with plenty of stunning views. Nothing hard about this walk. I would allow 2 to 3 hours to complete.

Weather can make or break.. Like all travellers, you have to take the weather as you find it. Such was the case in the long planned tour of Sydney and the Spit to Manly walk. Being prepared for all weather elements in an unseasonal period of Sydney weather, we took in the sights of the Spit Bridge and nearby boats and the occasional boathouse, as we wended our way across sandstone steps and winding paths. Barely into our walk the heavens opened and we were forced to shelter in a convenient marina at Sandy Bay to wait out the downpour. Most of the remainder of the walk took in spectacular harbour views, including long distance views of the Sydney Heads and the Manly Ferry as we made our way along the ever ascending and descending sets of steps of the walk path. At one point we found diverted to Grotto Point to take in primitive Aboriginal stone carvings of fish, whales and kangaroos. The big weather disappointment came within a few kilometers of Manly, when an approaching jogger warned us off the track due to heavy flooding. The resultant detour cost us several kilometers and considerable time in making a 2+ hour walk into a 3+ hour ( and very tiring) trek. None-the-less, the Spit to Manly walk is worth the effort and the views, including colourful flora, along the way make it very rewarding for the photographer.

Spectacular Views. The harbour is accessible to all and nowhere is it more so than on this walk. Pass the boats moored at the spit, stroll through suburbia and then through light bush until you're looking out across the heads. Its even more spectacular when the weather changes - if you're brave! Don't forget your camera.

Amazing views and wildlife. From the bridge to manly wharf bar it's about 10km and you get to see the sheer beauty of Sydney's north side. Some of the small secluded beaches are spectacular. Bring lunch and take your time to enjoy them!

A pleasant walk with good harbour views.. If you enjoy bush walking, the Spit to Manly walk is a good option when in the Sydney area and affords excellent views of the Harbour, City, and Manly. It follows the coast line from the Spit Bridge through bushland, and round a number of bays and inlets. Around 2 hours (assuming you aren't stopping too frequently). If travelling from the the city, a bus to the Spit, and the ferry back from Manly is what I'd recommend.

Worth the effort. We started at the Spit bridge and walked to Manly. Fantastic views of the natural beauty of the harbour, especially the Manly side. A long walk, with many steps, some quite steep. Some stepped areas currently under upgrade. The walk is teasing, as although Manly ferry area is in sight, the path goes well away as it follows the bay. It took us about 3 hours,as an older couple,but if you want to stop and look at all the side paths on the way, allow much longer. Make sure you walk it with enough light to finish, and when cooler but not wet, as it could be difficult on some of the steeply stepped areas. Manly is a great place to visit, with lots of places to eat after the effort.

Don't miss this. Whether you're an international or interstate visitor, or actually live in Sydney, this beautiful harbour side walk is a must-do. I grew up in this area and always love doing the Spit to Manly walk. The views are spectacular and while you're never very far from houses, there are parts where you really feel like you have 'escaped' the city. If you're moving at a good pace, it will take about 2 hours. Make sure you have water and sunscreen and if it's been raining, be careful as it can be a bit muddy and slippery. There are lots of cafes in Manly to grab a coffee and a bite at the end (try Cartel or Fika) and it's really easy to catch a bus back to the Spit bridge or a ferry back into the city.
good to do. the Manly walk is a nice thing to do for a morning stroll even better the Bridge do this if Your in Manly

Beautiful escape from town. My friend and I enjoyed this little hike, lots of uphill and downhill but you can take it at your own pace. Beautiful views across Manly. Made me feel like I was on holiday - which I was

Great views - interesting walk. You can get to this walk and back to central Sydney by public transport. The Harbour views are spectacular - the bush gives you an idea of the Sydney coast before European intervention. At the completion you can get the Manly ferry back - more wonderful harbour views.

Spectacular Sydney Harbour Coastal walk. We started our walk from the Spit Bridge which is located on the harbour side of the bridge, there is ample signage to direct you in the right direction. If in doubt just walk along the foreshore to Clontarf Beach and you will come across the bush track at the very end of the beach and once there the route is clearly marked. The walk took us about 2 hours with a few stops at spectacular vantage points to take snap shots of the views over Sydney Harbour. We were blessed to have the most glorious sunny day - there was a slight breeze and the sun sparkled on the water - the views are just magnificent and breathtaking! The walk itself I found fairly easy with well marked tracks and as it had rained a couple of day prior there were a few muddy areas yet just take your time stepping around or through the wet puddles. At the end of the walk you traverse through a park past quaint residential streets before hitting the busy Manly Wharf precinct. Once in Manly there are many established restaurants and fast food outlets at the ferry wharf together with the Manly Wharf Pub .The ferry will take you back to the city or catch a bus the city or along the jump off at The Spit Bridge to jump back into your car. I would suggest to go early morning before it gets too warm as there isn't always much shade. Do wear comfy walking shoes, wear a hat, take a camera or your mobile phone, a water bottle and a beach towel for a dip at Manly Beach. This beautiful coastal walk is a fun experience. Highly recommend it!

Sydney Harbour's secret. This walk is a great way to see different aspects of our beautiful harbour. Even on a cloudy day it's magnificent. Lots of small bays and sandy beaches with clean, clear water - great for a quick dip. You walk through a beautiful red gum forest and will see some wildflowers depending on the time of year. Choose a cool day if possible, bring lunch and water, wear comfy shoes and a hat. There are a lot of 'up' stairs if you start.from The Spit end, less if you start from Manly but I would recommend starting at The Spit because you do the hardest bit first when you are fresh, and the stroll into Manly is a lovely end to the walk.and there are lots of places for a cold drink or dinner in Manly. We love to go to the Steyne Hotel which overlooks the surfing beach. I'm 61 and not super fit but apart from the stairs which I find tiring, this walk is certainly doable. We allow about 4 1/2 hours which includes stopping for lunch as well as regular stops to enjoy the views. If coming from the city, catch a bus from Carrington Street behind Wynyard and alight BEFORE The Spit bridge. It's fun to walk across it and admire the view!

Great walk. On a clear day a great experience. Some paths a little tricky but overall a manageable walk for anybody with a reasonable level of fitness. Some excellent views over the harbour as well as out through the heads. Wide variety of scenery from suburban streets to bushland settings. Well worth the effort

Beautiful coastal walk!. 10 km- not a full bush walk, but some paths can be tricky for older people. Remember to wear comfortable closed toe shoes. Running shoes are the best. No hiking boots needed, but definitely no flip flops. Dont bring too much stuff ie heavy backpack, tricky handbags, carrying phone+wallet+keys+book+etc on hand, etc. Travel light! The 10km is so worth it. Beautiful scenery. Breathtaking landscape. Worth doing. Can split the walk into two times: Spit Bridge to Manly. Then Manly to North Head for another time. Otherwise... it will take 5 hours. Spit Bridge to Manly took us about 3 hours and 45 mins, but we were with our parents. So, I think it could be done in 3 hours? Then Manly to North Head for another day of outting :)

Northern Beaches Walk. I have done this walk three times, all starting from the Spit Bridge. It is a little difficult finding the track around Clontarf, but otherwise the route is clearly marked. Views over Sydney Harbour are magnificent, particularly on a sparkling, sunny day. The approach into Manly, with its cosmopolitan feel is superb, Once at Manly there are many activities to engage in. There is also a bus to get back to The Spit, where you may have left your car for the start of the walk.

Very nice walk. This walk is pretty long, it took us just above 3 hours to cover the distance. It is not too intense, but there are a few uphill stretches which makes it a bit challenging. The walk is very pleasant with some great views and scenery changing between beaches, hills, rocks, bushes and suburban streets.
Fantastic walk. It seems amazing such a walk which at times feels so remote and in the wilderness is interspersed with great views of Sydney Harbour. A wonderful free attraction.
Great walk. We did the 10km walk from Spit to Manly wharf. Some of the walk is similar to the one in the blue mountains with the ocean added as a bonus.

Do it!. We got the bus to drop us off just before the bridge and followed the drivers advice to head to the pathway. En route met a wonderful chap from the UK and enjoyed 3 hours of brilliant scenic torture. The views were stunning and we'd often feel we could "touch" Manly, only to find another bay ahead. We couldn't believe it when we landed in North Harbour to see. "2km" sign! However the exhilaration was amazing and the drink in the Manly Wien Bar afterwards was well earned.Don't come to Sydney to see only the man-made wonders. Take time, to enjoy the natural environment and you won't be disappointed.

Another gem on the harbour. This can be ordinary or special. If you follow the normal route it has great views etc and a pleasant walk. It doesn't matter where you start, The Spit or Manly. There is food at both ends and a bus to return you to your starting point at the end, unless you have 2 cars.The special way to do it is find out when the tide is going OUT and start at Manly and walk over the rocks which are high and dry. Then climb up at Crater Cove and join the walking track. You can do it the opposite way if you can find the track down to the cottages at Crater Cove and then down to the rocks. Its a bit more difficult to start with but worth it either way.We have done it often and never had a problem, but don't risk the tide coming in unless you start right at or just before low tide. You will be able to scramble up along the rocks but you need to know where the track is to join it.Have fun. Take shoes that may get wet and are comfortable on rocks.

You won't regret doing this. This walk has two routes - Manly to Spit Bridge (10km) and Manly to North Head (9.5km). We decided to take this route for ease of logistics.The trail itself is well marked and easy to follow - not easy to get lost unless you try really hard. You will also find that this trail is able to cater to various needs for different people - the tourists (like us), health freaks (runners, joggers, walkers etc), families & friends (catch up sessions), pet owners with their pet dogs* and even couples on dates! Having said this, it is not suitable for families with young children or strollers. You will be walking on wooden platforms, sand paths, gravel paths, steps cut out of stones, the beach, pavement and even lanes through the houses in the suburbs. Not all routes are dog-friendly, watch out for alternate routes. Also, in cases where it is high tide (makes you wonder what the actual route is like right?), there will be alternate routes for you to take to continue the walk.There at least 20 points of interest. The main attraction however would be the breath taking views you will be rewarded with. Along the way, we also discovered that Manly is home to the endangered Little Penguins and it is the only mainland breeding colony in New South Wales. Cute little "Watch Out Penguins About" signs are visible on the pathway. Some tips if you are planning to do this: - wear walking/sport shoes or comfortable footwear - apply plenty of sunblock as you are exposed to the sun alot (or you can wear a light long sleeve t-shirt. You'll sweat a bit more but at least the skin is protected).- bring ample of water (recommended 1 liter per person) - bring along light snacks - carry along a raincoat/poncho. Umbrella might not be suitable at certain areas. - don't forget your camera. Getting there and back: We took the bus to Spit Bridge and the ferry back to Circular Quay. You can read more of my Manly Scenic Walk experience on my blog - http://arazlin.blogspot.com.au/2014/03/manly-scenic-walk.html.
Nice views. Great overall experience and good to get out og the city and see the local areas. Great harbor views, beaches, residential area makes me want to move there.

One of the Best!. This is billed as one of the most scenic walks in the world and it lives up to its billing. We got the bus from Circular Quay to Spit Bridge about 25 minutes. Go straight ahead when you get off over the bridge and go down steps to start the walk, far safer than trying to cross the busy road. Lovely views form the outset, but they get better. The whole walk is about 10 kms and takes about 4 hours. Take plenty of water, sun screen and a hat. There are a lot of steps but it is worth it! The scenery is wonderful. We have done the walk three times now and never tire of it, gets better every time. A lovely combination of bush and coastal beach scenery.

Bush and Water. I have done this walk many times and never fail to be impressed that such a great walk exists in the middle of Sydney.At both ends (Manly and The Spit) there are a choice of transport options and cafes and restaurants. In between is a bush walk that offers magnificent harbour views and some good heart pumping ups and downs. Along the way one can take a side trip to small beaches, a lighthouse and view some aboriginal rock carvings.At the end a well deserved beer or soft drink can easily be had whilst still admiring the wonder of Sydney Harbour.

Beautiful bush walk, lovely scenery. An amazing walk to take, around 10 km of beach, bush and wonderful scenery. I enjoyed walking it in the afternoon, when it's not too hot and then have a lovely dinner in one of the many restaurants that Manly has. Easy to follow signs and they also let you know how far along you've come, not a very tough walk even though it is marked as relatively hard.

A Walk worth doing. This walk was amazing and spectacular scenery. The walk is about 10km and it is the one of the best walks I have done in Sydney so far. The walk is pretty easy to follow as there are signs all the way through. Just make sure you get a lot of water and some snacks on the way :). I really encourage you to do this walk as it does have fantastic scenery all the way.

Spectacular scenery. This is a wonderful walk of about 10 Km. Some small hills and stairs and a mild challenge but the views are spectacular across to Middle and south Head . You can head down the edge of the harbour and have a swim and a picnic or end the walk as we did at the Four Pines brewery for a cold beer and a great lunch.Well worth the effort!

Blow away the cobwebs with this spectacular walk!. A great way to see some of the coastline around Sydney. The walk is about 11km - make a day of it as it takes you through wonderful scenery, through the trees along the cliff top and down to beaches along the way. There are lots of ups and downs but its easy walking as the route is well marked, lots of work has been done to provide steps and paths. It hugs the cliffs and gives you opportunities to break your walk with an ice cream or beer at any number of the beaches crossed along the way. Get a bus to the Spit to start your walk or park on one of the roads near the bridge - and taxi back from Manly (unless you are super energetic and want to walk back!

Feels remote but is central. Take a bus to Spit Bridge (the drivers all know about the walk) walk across the bridge to the north side and the walk starts to the left of the bridge - you then walk under the bridge and you're off. At the end you can take the Manly ferry back to Circular Quay. We bought a day pass for all forms of public transport for $23 in a convenience store.The walk itself is great - you need a reasonable level of fitness. You'll discover flowers, plants, the Eastern Water Dragon, secret beaches. The path is well marked and sections are being sensitively restored by stone masons. You'll need 2.5 - 3 hours. Take water.

A great experience for all the family. This is one of the iconic Sydney walks - it can be done from either the Spit or from Manly - either way offer fantastic views of Sydney Harbour - along the way there are a few places to stop and have a bite to eat - including 40 Beans at North Harbour and Clonnys at Clontarf. During summer you may be lucky to strike the ice cream man at Tania Park. My tip is to do the walk early before the heat of the day - and if you are in a group or a slow walker please move out of the way for runners.

Secret beaches are not the prime attraction...There is heeps more!!. For an experience that showcases the diversity of Sydney Harbour,there is nothing to beat the Spit Bridge to Manly Walk. While gawking at the mammoth houses that line the shores of Clontarf,we were floored by the amount of secret beaches at Castle Rock reserve. Our gentle meander included smaller tracks that adjoin the main walkway.... 10 km in all. We took five hours including lunch at Reef Beach. I would suggest to bring towel,swimmers and snorkelling gear and good shoes to slip in and out of. Showers are available at all the spots. So here is the plan. Hop on a bus at Wynyard disembarking at Spit Junction and once you crossed the bridge on foot,turn right onto the trail. the walk is well-signed,with detours for those looking for of-track adventures. The terrain is varied. One minute you will be walking on cement footpath,sandy trail the next followed by rock staircases. The views that greet you towards North and South Heads are second to none. Absolutely spectacular,with wildlife spotting a certainty. At Grotto point there are aboriginal engravings giving a background to the history of this area. Once you get to Manly reward yourself with a long and cool drink or late lunch before catching the ferry back to Circular Quay. By the way,if you sit on the right-hand side of the ferry,you can see some of the coastline you have just walked along,albeit, with a different perspective of the beaches and lookouts you have just visited. Pretty neat.

10km of natural bush land and great views. I love this walk and do it a few times a year. You walk through lots of natural bush land and past some cute beaches like Forty Baskets and Clontarf, both have toilets and water. The walk is better at low tide - wear proper shoes. If starting from the Spit walk the first 2.5km may seem a little tame before reaching Clontarf then it gets a bit more rugged as you climb up over headlands (stairs provided by the national park service).

Manley to Spit Bridge. This walk is not like Coogee to Bondi (less people and not many cafe's to stop at) .. You will experience beautiful forest, cliff edges, bush, rocks, lots of lizards and not many ppl around! Its incredible how such a huge National Park is in the middle of Sydney. There aren't that many cafe's you walk past on the treck so be sure to have some water n snacks packed just incase - there were couple toilets not the treck and lots of good signs to follow. Its a 2-3hour walk and its better to start at Spit Bridge and make your way to Manley. You can get a bus from Wynard Station to Spit then get ferry back to Circular key from Manley. Lots of small little beaches to stop off for a dip!! Great to do alone or with friends. Enjoy =)

Fantastic walk. We live in Sydney, but I had never done this entire walk before (only some small sections). Its fantastic - I did it with my 12 and 9 year olds. It took us nearly 4.5 hours, but that's because we had lunch at Clontarf, stopped at most of the little harbour beaches for a play, and stopped to admire the scenery. Our only regret was we didn't have our swimmers with us ... having dressed in walking clothes! A dip in the water would have been refreshing as it was a really hot day.!

Highly recommend. This is a fabulous walk, I loved every minute of it and the scenery is amazing. I caught the ferry into Manly and visited the Hello Manly visitor centre to get some information and the girls there suggested that I do the Manly to Spit or Spit to Manly walk. I caught the bus to Spit bridge (so I could end the walk in Manly) and began the walk. I swam at little beaches along the way and had an amazing time...the people on the walk were so friendly. Love love love

Great bush walk. This was a fantastic walk, 2-3 hours, I think 10k. There are lots of spots to stop and take photos. We took the bus out to Spit bridge in the morning, just ask the bus driver to let you know when to get off, and after several small coves and beaches, some hills and stairs through the bush, you arrive in Manly, nice and hungry for lunch. Bring water, we didn't see any drinking fountains along the way. There are a few little off shoots to the trail to head out to the cliffs for nice view points, sign posts guide you along the route. We saw several quite sizeable lizards, great fun, would recommend.

My favourite walk in Sydney. An absolute must for any local or tourist. Catch a bus from the city to the Spit bridge and enjoy the 2-3 hour walk through bushland and along the coast - there are maps/signposts along the way so you shouldnt get lost. On they way you will have some fantastic views of the heads, and Manly is the perfect place to finish the walk enjoying a nice cold drink at one of the many restaurants or bars. Its easy to get back to the city with buses and a ferry option.A general level of fitness is required but the walk isnt too steep and has a clear path with steps (no bush bashing). Maybe dont wear thongs! I see alot of people in some truly terrible footwear, proper shoes will be more comfortable. Lastly, some sections cant be accessed during high tide so you will have to take the alternative route on the road.

Best walk in Sydney. If you can only do one walk in Sydney, this is the one - although Taronga to Balmoral runs a close second. This walk can be done in either direction, but Spit Bridge to Manly is best for pub and food options at the end and a ferry back to Circular Quay. The harbour and city skyline views are spectacular; the landscape changes from rainforest gullies to wildflower-strewn heathland to cliffs and beaches; wildlife runs to eastern water dragons, a variety of birds, occasionally dolphins and rarely fairy penguins.This walk is popular on weekends, so opt for a weekday if you prefer nature uninterrupted by cyclists and joggers. Take water. There's little in the way of food and drink along the way.

Great views of Sydney harbour.. A two to three hour walk on an established path around the Sydney harbour foreshore [the most beautiful harbour in the world].Take your camera for some fantastic shots.

It's just gotta be done. I've done this walk in whole and in parts and it never fails to disappoint. The views are spectacular and at times it is hard to believe that you are in the middle of Sydney. You go from the water's edge to cliff top views of Sydney Harbour and back down again. My favourite section is Reef Beach to Castle Rock Beach. That covers Crater Cove, Dobroyd Head and Castle Rock Beach. We've done that with a 6 year old, who had no problems. The paths are well maintained and well sign posted. On a sunny day, this is an unbeatable experience.

Must do. It was the highlight of our week in Sydney. The walk from the Spit hugs the coast then takes you up the cliffs for some great views of the CBD before dropping down into bustling Manly. There are a couple of spots early on in the walk to have a swim at one of the small beaches on the route.We hired kayaks at the Spit as well and paddled around the protected bays having a look at all the impressive yachts.

The walk. This is the best bushwalk in Sydney, starting from below the Spit bridge at the bottom of Seaforth, you will walk through the bush, on top of breathtaking cliff overlooking the 2 heads of the Sydney Harbour Bridge before descending towards Manly where you will be able to catch a ferry back to the CBD. Don't miss out on a great day out!

Essential Bridge. This is certainly a great bridge, particularly for residents on the Manly peninsula. Best not to travel that way during the times that it opens to let the tall yachts etc. go in or out of there when mooring or sight seeing in that area.
Awesome. My son and I walked from Manly to the Spit and then back to Manly. It was an amazing experience. The views are exceptional. I cant wait to do it again.

Engineering, natural beauty and choices. Check out this bridge as you commence the wonderful Spit to Manly walk. Otherwise check it out before you enjoy drinks at the 16ft skiffs club. Whatever your energy levels this bridge and the waterway are great viewing.

A pretty place to wander.. Go for a walk on the sand or go fishing. Some nice places to eat though some are pricey. In peak hour it's not so good but weekends are quieter traffic wise. Still can be hard to find a car park as restaurants there are popular. Good place to start the walk to Manly.

Awesome. You really do need to be very fit for this walk. If you are, it is well worth doing. Make sure you take lots of water with you, as there is none on the track. I tend to walk from Manly, to the Spit, and then walk across the bridge, and catch a bus to the city. The views on the walk are awesome, so make sure you take your camera with you. There is a small cafe in a wall near the end of the walk, near the public toilets, behind a larger restaurant, at the spit, which does nice cheese and tomato toasted sandwiches, and hot chips. If you are in Sydney for a few days, I suggest you get the weekly day tripper pass, which costs about 3 times the daily day tripper pass price, but lasts for a week. Then you can catch buses, trains, and ferries, all using the same pass, which is most helpful if you are staying in Manly, but are going to the city most days.

Great walk !. I completed this 10Km walk with my son during a recent visit to Sydney. I really enjoyed it as It is such an interesting varied walk with great views of the harbour . A certain level of fitness is required as there are inclines, numerous steps, narrow rocky paths, and road walking involved. The scenery is really nice and there are areas to rest or have a picnic. if you remember to bring your togs, you can even go for a swim ! On the day we walked-- a Monday-- the walkway was quiet --there were few walkers and no joggers. Watch out for the wildlife-- hedgehogs, lizards and numerous birds. Manly was our destination where we had some delicious ice cream and a stroll around before taking the ferry back to Circular Quay. Brilliant day out .

Will definitely do it again. I have a new favourite walk in Sydney. It takes around 2 hours (at a reasonable place and no stops), but not only is a great workout but some lovely scenery along the way. My only caveat would be to be careful in wet weather as it would get a little slippery in some places. You would also want to have a reasonable level of fitness to do the full walk.

Seeing more of Sydney. Based on a friend's suggestion, undertook the Spit Bridge to Manly walk on a pleasant and sunny Saturday morning. 10km walk, provides some interesting and contrasting scenery, and certainly an aerobic workout with the regular climbing of stairs along the pathway. Depending on what pace and fitness level you are, may take 2 to 3 hours to walk the path (though those fit people running it would do it in the hour). Wear some good shoes, quite a few spots where it is wet from the natural water run offs that make some areas a little slippery.
Spectacular views. All visitors to Sydney should make the effort to to cross Spit Bridge. The first sight is quite amazing and a memory to keep forever.
Spit Bridge to Manly walk. Great coastal walk, it's quite easy, at some point you need to get your feet wet to cross the beach, don't do like me and do remove your shoes :)

Where to go if you're an engineer.. If you love bridges, you have to see the Spit Bridge in action. Traffic stops in either direction as the bridge lifts into the air to let the boats through. It's definitely a sight to see.

one of the best views in Sydney. Driving down from Mosman on to the Spit would have to be one of the best views in Sydney. It is not the main harbour, but the homes, boats and shimmering water is stunning. If you are in a hurry, avoid crossing the bridge when it opens.Avoid peak hour as there are not enough lanes on the return to Sydney journey.

Stunning Spit Bridge to Manly Coastal Walk. When the local tourist office tells you this is the most beautiful coastal walk in the world you have to be sceptical - but this must be pretty close! It takes around three hours of undulating coastal walking but it is worth it as you pass along the edge of numerous beautiful bays and beaches and have great coastal views from the clifftops. There are also several bars and restrooms along the walk so you can enjoy the walk in a degree of comfort too. This walk is well worth the effort !

Geography unfairly favoured Sydney. Park your car on north side of Spit Bridge. The views only get better as you progress on the shore and cliff lines overlooking the Harbour. Great winter day walks with good restaurants at Manly. Afterward take the ferry to Circular Quay or the Chatswood bus back to Spit Bridge.

A tourist track that's off the tourist trail. I'm giving this 5* because I only met about 10 people, even though it's the end of November and it was a hot day. If it was busy, I wouldn't like it so much. It took me 3 hours, and perhaps I should have given myself more time to stop off and swim, for example. I saw lizards, various birds and flying fish, a few yachts and kayakers, lots of fancy houses, and a great mix of terrains. I took the bus from Manly to Spit (143/144, stance D opposite the ferry) and walked towards Manly, so it was nice and quiet in the first stage. The final bit, walking through Manly, was a bit less interesting - a wander through the suburb - but was ok because it meant a beer was near.Some bits of the path near Spit Bridge are very narrow and pretty steep.
Stunning walk that requires a little bit of effort. Allow 2-3 hrs & take sunscreen & water. Requires a reasonable level of fitness. Amazing, amazing views.

Walk the Harbour's northside.. This walk is fabulous! A short bus ride from the city takes you to the Spit bridge, then the walk takes you through local streets, national park (with Aboriginal drawings to see) and to lots of lovely little harbour beaches. We even bought an ice cream from a guy who sells them from his boat! Ending up n manly is great, for dinner and a ferry ride back to the city.

An Interesting Bridge. As you drive from Sydney to Manly you can go over the Spit Bridge. What's special about this bridge is: its age, the fact that it opens up to let boats through & as you come down the hill, on the approach to the bridge, you can see the incredible waterfront mansions & the sea of private yachts at the marina. As a child, I remember there was a special sound the road made as you drove over a certain part of the bridge & so I called it the 'Singing Bridge'. If you drive this way to Manly see if the bridge sings for you.

What's there NOT to like?. I've been over it, and under it, innumerable times, but on the way to or from somewhere else. What makes it so special is its position in the upper reaches of Middle Harbour, where yachts congregate until the bridge span opens to allow them through - to the intense annoyance and frustratrion of motoriosts travelling to/from the northern suburbs of Sydney south toward the city. One correction: it's NOT at Manly! It's either at Mosman/Balgowlah on one side, or Seaforth on the other, but it's many kilometres from Manly.

An absolute highlight - from a sydneysider. OK - not everyone loves walking. some prefer being driven around in an airless tourist bus, occasionally stopping for a photo opp. Good on them. For those who actually like to get feel, see, smell, inbibe the atmosphere of a place, this is one of the absolute highlights of a visit to Sydney. a stunning 9km/6 mile walk that you will never forget - and yes, there are more photo opportunities than you can shake a stick out. If you can't do this one, do the Rose Bay to Watson's Bay coastal walk which is easier to access by ferry and bus. Enjoy.

Great walk well sign posted. the wildflowers at the moment are breath taking. The perfect view once you get to Dobroyd is well worth it. Well sign posted and the walkway is well maintained. plenty of spots to stop for photos or pack a lunch and have a picnic on the way.
Spit Bridge. Cross this bridge many times and even boat under it. location is beautiful the area is great stop and walk around. Lots of nice bays beaches in the area.

Great views out over the harbour. A really nice walk; I find it better to start at the Spit Bridge and finish at Manly (catch a bus from Sydney CBD and get off at the bridge).Great views of the harbour and a few interesting Aboriginal rock carvings to be seen.Be warned though, it's a 10km walk, most over fairly well maintained and even tracks.
Yatching Fun. Had the opportunity to sail through there some time ago and it was great and also had dinner for mothers day there once and it was great.

The link between the north shore and the northern beaches,,,,. A great spot for a wander on a sunny weekend. Stop and have lunch at one of the restaurants....gaze at the boats at the marina....wander along the sand and watch the sunbathers at clovelly across the water.Or...simply wait in the traffic queue for the bridge to rise up and let the boats through.....its funny how watching the boats sail under the bridge is so relaxing from the deck of the restaurant....., yet watching it from behind the wheel of your car is utter frustration....go figure....
Fishing. We like to go fishing in some of the spots around manly bridge good for site seeing and love to watch the bridge when it opens.

Walking Trail. If you looking for a great walking trail, then try the Spit Bridge to Manly walking trail. From Sydney cross over the Spit Bridge, then walk down underneath the bridge where you will find the trail which is well sign posted. Follow to this Manly keeping the water on your right. Its about a 10km walk.Take in Manly, have lunch and then enjoy a ferry trip to circular quay. A cheap sea journey and agreat day all round.The walk is terrific and the are lots of shady gum trees and small beaches along the way if it's hot and you want a swim, or just chill out and watch whats happening on the harbour.Take some water with you and a hat.

The Manly to Spit Bridge Walk is the attraction..... Seems a few reviewers didn't realise that the Spit Bridge isnt the attraction, it is the walk to the bridge itself.If you're in the city, catch the Manly ferry over to Manly Wharf and the walk starts as you alight.Approx. 2 hours of walking along the harbour, beaches, national parks and headlands takes you to your final finishing spot - the Spit Bridge (or you could do it the other way around).Both start and finish line and scattered with bars and restaurants however, the in-between consists of views, Nature, Hiking Trails, and Secluded Beaches.A beautiful was to start your daym finished with a long lunch. It really is a must do in Manly.

The Spit Bridge of Manly. The Spit Bridge of Manly - its a fantastic structure to look at from a boat below, but when you drive over it, it just has this magnificent sweep to it BUT it is a horror drive in peak hour traffic

Wow, amazing views!. Walked from Manly ferry terminal west along the coastal path bound for "The Spit" bridge. I knew Sydney was a picturesque place but was amazed at the beauty nonetheless. A longer walk than I expected taking about 3.5 hours but worth it. If you find it too long just turn around. Plenty of beaches along the way for a swim and great views. Mostly easy walking but gets rocky and more difficult on occasions. You can return to Manly on the 143 or 144 bus. There is a bus stop on the city (south) side of the bridge (bus stop is about 100 metres back from the start of the bridge). This walk is a must see in Sydney.

Spit Bridge and important link. The Spit Bridge is an important link from Manly and the Northern Beaches by raod into the Sydney Central business district. This bridge opens several times each day to allow boating craft with tall sails to pass through. The scenery around the Spit is winderful and many boats and yachts are moored there. There are several restaurants there.

Bridge opens for water traffic.. The view, the multi million dollar boats, yachts and houses. Just don't get caught if your driving at bridge opening times. Advertised on RTA website. Traffic around this area is atrocious in peak hours and weekends.
Little bit of the outer Harbour. Great place for a meal and a look at the affluent marine craft of the area.

Best walk in Sydney. The Spit Bridge to Manly coastal walk has to be one of the best walks in Sydney, taking in bush, beaches, bays and the most stunning views of the heads of the harbour. A 7km walk one way, and quite steep in places but well worth it. Park at Spit Bridge and taken the bus back from Manly and don't forget to pack swimmers for along the way.
Spit Bridge to Manly Harbour walk. Such an incredible walk. So beautiful. Easy trek, and end with a beer at the harbour before a ferry back to Circular Quay.

Part of a great walk to Manly or to Mosman - or you could sail under!. A unique bridge and great to see when it goes up ..... unless you are one of the cars who was too late to get past before it goes up. Some good sailing or boating around here and some great places to walk or play by the sandy beaches

Spit Bridge to Manly walk. The best walk in Sydney which takes approx. 2.5 hours if you don't stop for a swim at one of the numerous beaches along the way. At the end you can enjoy a great meal at Manly to reward youself.

Fantastic walk - takes about 4 hours. I love this walk and have done it about 6 or 7 times.Mostly I have done it in the direction Manly to the Spit. Get a ferry to Manly from Circular Quay. The start of the walk is near the harbour beach beside the aquarium (not the ocean beach). It is well signposted and the views are really great. Doing it at an easy pace takes us 4 hours. When you arrive at the Spit bridge you can get a bus back to Manly (go up the steps to the road, turn right (not back over the bridge, the other way), then after about 200 metres a road goes to the left and just at that junction is where you get the bus). Takes about 10 or 15 minutes to get back to Manly. I have never made it in time for lunch, more like dinner in Manly. Then a ferry back to Sydney and that is a really great way to spend a day.

Spit bridge to manly walking trail. This is a beautiful walk but there are parts that require a fair amount of energy so I would not recommend it to older people or unfit people. The views are gorgeous and I recommend you start early in hotter weather as there are parts that do not have as much shade. Wear sunscreen and enjoy a lovely lunch at Manly at the end. You can then take the ferry back into the city if you wish.
Great for lunch. There are a few restaurants on the water near the Spit Bridge that are worth a visit. Spend a long lunch looking out over the harbour in luxury!

Fantastic walk for those who want a view with their exercise. A fabulous walk from the Spit Bridge to Manly along the coastline. Start early - takes about 3 hrs, and finish in Manly for a fabulous seafood lunch. Have done the walk several times, best in spring or autumn when the weather is at its best.
Spit to Manly walk is wonderful.. The walk is a wonderful way to spend half a day with great views along teh way. Expensive parking

The Spit Bridge (NOT in Manly). I don't know who put together this article - the Spit Bridge, Spit Road, Spit, is exactly 3.5 miles, or 5.6 km, from The Corso, Manly.I've walked , I've driven , I've rode a bike from The Spit to The Corso, Manly. But, don't take my word for it - try Google.
